Defendant: Yes, because she had electrical outlets in the kitchen overloading the system. The building is from 1927, and the 120-volt will not support it.

Judge: Did the electrician do any electrical work, yes or no?

Defendant: He did.

Judge: Okay, so what did the landlord tell you?

Plaintiff: She said I'm overloading it by putting too much stuff. She said it's because I brought in a freezer inside there.

Judge: Right, so she told you to get the freezer out, but what happened?

Plaintiff: I had meat in the freezer, and she gave me a small refrigerator that couldn't fit my meat.

Judge: Okay, I understand. When did the problems arise between you and your landlord besides the electricity? Was it in April?

Plaintiff: Well, from my move-in...

Defendant: She came to inspect the apartment in May. She said I have to have everything unpacked by that time.

Judge: But okay, why? What do you care whether she unpacks or not?

Defendant: Oh, that's incorrect. From the day that Monica moved in, I'd like to tell you that she violated the lease. The first thing was she changed the locks without my authorization.

Judge: Okay, that's a violation of the lease. You also had... she was obviously a hoarder. She had clothes piled five feet high, and I have pictures and a video of it, which is another violation. She had a china closet blocking the window, which is another fire hazard. She had personal clothing in the common area of the building.

Judge: Wait, okay, so that the kitchen... that is the kitchen, right? What's that white thing?

Defendant: That is actually the refrigerator, brand new. That's your refrigerator?

Defendant: That's right. So that's the before. This is the kitchen after she moved her stuff in, and you can see the china closet is covering the window, which is a clear fire hazard. So that's the after.

Judge: Let me just ask you a question. If no one else lives there, what skin is it off your nose if someone decides to do something stupid in their own house that they're renting from you? Is that a violation that you get a chance to complain about?

Defendant: Yes, it is because, well, first of all, my father was FDNY, so I know very much about fire hazards.

Judge: But who does it make unsafe for besides herself?

Defendant: Herself, but it's also... but she can't sue you for it if she decided to put that there. You didn't do it.

Judge: Well, we live in a very litigious society, so who knows how people can come up with frivolous suits. Okay, I'm sorry, we're talking... why are you interrupting?

Defendant: But also, you can see all the items that are there, which is the fire hazard as well. So that was just one facet of the fire hazard. If you go to the next page, that's the before room, and then you can look at the actual... no, you can't even walk in there. Good Lord.

Judge: Okay, that's a fire hazard in the sense of what you have declared, and I realize you're the daughter of a New York firefighter, but you have declared that having all that stuff is a fire hazard, and I'm not sure... I'm not sure like she's not storing combustibles.

Defendant: She just... that's what I'm trying to tell you. She had a propane gas tank in the apartment as well.

Judge: Oh, get out of here.

Defendant: Yes, she did.

Judge: Did you have that inside of the house?

Plaintiff: Is being a hoarder a fire hazard?

Judge: I think it can be with a propane gas tank in the apartment.

Defendant: Yes, I think it can be.

Judge: What you say? Yes, I think so too. I don't think there's any question going inside the courtroom.

Plaintiff: I moved with it, not to keep it there because I have an outdoor...

Judge: So did you ever move it out?

Plaintiff: Yes, I took it into storage. No, I took it out because it was a fire hazard.

Judge: Okay, when... okay, when the people moved me in, they just brought the thing, so I had to move...

Judge: Who are the people? These weren't professional movers? These were like your friends and relatives?

Plaintiff: No, they were movers.

Judge: So when they moved the things in, they did not... so what... how long did you tell her you got to go?

Defendant: So after I tried to bring the exterminator to actually do the regular extermination, that's when I... the exterminator couldn't even move in there because the exterminator couldn't do anything. Nobody could... forget about it, as they say. You couldn't do anything in there because they say here... so then, after I discovered that, I said I needed to come and inspect. I gave her a certain amount of time to correct.

Judge: And you told her, "Unpack your stuff and live like a person," and then...

Defendant: Well, I didn't say unpack. I'm just saying, listen, you have to make it so that you can walk in, or I can get anything done. It was just... and so after that, I kept sending her notes. Listen, I need to do the initial inspection.

Judge: Who else lived in that building?

Defendant: Another... I have a letter also from the other tenant in the building describing her bad behavior.

Judge: Yes, did... why was it that you weren't unpacked? You can't live like that. Why... why was it you weren't... I'm just curious.

Plaintiff: This is when I moved in because I moved in the things in the car. She wasn't there during your move.

Judge: Okay, she came afterwards, and according to you, how long after? A month? May?

Plaintiff: Yes, May. After a month, moved in April 1st. She takes the pictures in May, you say.

Judge: So what... so yes, then normal people are asking, why does it look like this after a month?

Plaintiff: Those clothes were sitting on my bed. I was unpacking them to fold them to put in my... it's me alone. It's myself. They were on my bed.

Defendant: According to the other tenant, she says that you would hang your loads of smelly personal clothing in the common area of the building, and that that tenant spoke to the landlord about moving it. That you cluttered the backyard with ladders, tires, garbage pails, dirt, and plants, and that you didn't dispose of your garbage properly, as there were Popeyes chicken bones and garbage thrown in the back, which resulted in maggots and an unsanitary situation right under her window. I have a picture of that too.

Judge: We were very happy after she left. Let me see the picture of the maggots.

Defendant: Okay, look at the maggots.

Judge: Yes, this is while she was still living there?

Defendant: Yes, he always took the garbage out, the first-floor tenant, but then he kept going back there, and there were chicken bones, Popeyes stuff...

Judge: That when you're finished. Yeah, so anyway, the disposal... she wasn't following those rules either. Okay, go ahead. Let me give you a chance to respond.

Plaintiff: The downstairs where those clothes are... there's a closet downstairs as you walk in. Those clothes there, I just lifted my clothes out of the car, and I hung them there with the intention to bring them upstairs.

Judge: I don't buy that because there was enough time for the tenant to get angry, for the tenant to bring it to her attention, for her to go over, and for her to take pictures, which we all know happened a month after you moved in. So that's not... you do... oh, I put them there for a second. That's not true, and that's the common area. Those bugs she showed you in the back, those bags in the back...

Plaintiff: Yeah, those bags in the back, I had a freezer when I moved there. I moved with a freezer. I told her before I moved that I have a refrigerator, stove...

Judge: And she told you you couldn't bring appliances there?

Plaintiff: No, no, no, she said I could store them in her garage because it's empty. No one is using it, so I could store my things in there.

Judge: So I put... that doesn't mean you can plug them in and create an electricity hazard.

Plaintiff: Okay, what I am by the way is relevant because if you're creating an electricity hazard, now we've got something that's going to light up all those boxes and clothes.

Judge: I did not create... okay, I didn't.

Plaintiff: There is the meat from the freezer. I had to take them. I put them... there's no reason why there should be maggots in... if you know you're putting away meat, then go dispose of it properly so the maggots don't come.

Judge: I didn't see no maggots. I don't know what's that.

Defendant: Those are maggots.

Judge: I was there, and I didn't see them.

Defendant: Those are maggots, and according to the neighbor, that was right under his window.

Plaintiff: It's not true. They are lying.

Judge: Look, you know, when I was in law school, the place where myself and my four roommates lived... this fellow had the poor taste to rent out his place to five law students. He actually went around and wrote us a nasty letter about numerous things that he didn't want to happen again, including my underwear was on the floor. Okay, if I want my underwear on the floor of a place I am paying rent for, my underwear is going to live on the damn floor, and you are a dirty old man for writing me a letter discussing my underwear on an unannounced visit in my place. Okay, so you couldn't get a more sympathetic judge to the fact that you're renting the place and that you need to have privacy. However, this is not somebody walking in the day after you move in. This is somebody who told you, "I'm going to come in and do an inspection." It's right in your lease that she's going to walk in and do an inspection. Okay, she has to worry about another family who's living there. You're putting in plugs in places where overloading the electrical circuitry, and then you've got a storage room going on there. And she doesn't say get out. She says you've got x amount of time to cure, and then you don't, and then she says you got to get out. You're in default, and then you leave, and then she keeps one month's security. There were two months' security on the table. She returned the other security, but she kept one month. Why? Because you signed a lease that specifically says she can do that if you default, and that's the reason why you have to leave. It's right in the lease. Right? Did you read the lease?

Plaintiff: I didn't. I didn't. I don't remember that that was there.

Judge: I'm calling it. She has a right to keep one of the two security deposits. I find that you're the one who defaulted. My verdict in this case is for the defendant. Thank you
manipulation_techniques: evasion,deflection, playing the victim,gaslighting, emotional appeal

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand.

Judge: Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket—the plaintiff says the defendant towed his 2010 Maxima, but the defendant says his tow truck caused no damage. It's the case of Maxima displeasure.

Judge: Derek Brinson, you are suing the tow company, represented here by Frankie Gonzalez. You're an employee, correct?

Defendant: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: But you have authority by the owner to represent?

Defendant: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: Okay. And you've asked us not to use the name of the tow company. We'll respect that. You're suing for $397.39 in bumper damage that you say you sustained as a result of their tow. Tell me what happened on March 1st.

Plaintiff: I bought a brand-new car. I had previously had a car before that, which was a Honda 2000. I got the car brand new with only 2,000 miles on it.

Judge: What year is it?

Plaintiff: It's a 2010.

Judge: Okay. You bought it when?

Plaintiff: I bought it on March 1st of 2012.

Judge: How could it be brand new? It’s years old.

Plaintiff: I apologize, but it only had 2,000 miles on it.

Judge: All right. It’s new to you. You said "brand new" like four times.

Plaintiff: It had no damages. I had switched my plates from my old car to the new car. I realized I had tickets. I didn’t think I had that many tickets, but I had tickets.

Judge: You had how many?

Plaintiff: I had eight.

Judge: What were the tickets for?

Plaintiff: Pretty much no parking, no parking, no parking, next to a fire hydrant, and one of them was failure to stop at a red light.

Judge: Were all these tickets with your new car or with your old car?

Plaintiff: They followed my plate.

Judge: So you had these tickets for how long? How many years?

Plaintiff: Not years, no. It’s in the span of September 9th to February 2nd.

Judge: September 9th of what year?

Plaintiff: Of 2011 to February 2nd of 2012.

Judge: So why are you letting them pile up?

Plaintiff: Honestly, like I said, I only received two in the mail. I thought I had only two tickets, honestly.

Judge: What are you talking about? The tickets on your windshield when you go to the car.

Plaintiff: Oh yeah. Oh yeah.

Judge: But you have a short attention span?

Plaintiff’s Parent: (Laughs)

Judge: Are those your parents?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Right. And is this how he was growing up?

Plaintiff’s Parent: (Laughs) Yes.

Judge: So you ignore all the tickets. How does that work out for you?

Plaintiff: Not good.

Judge: Not good at all, right? Because what happens?

Plaintiff: My car gets towed away.

Judge: Now, you guys actually have a contract with the city where you just go around running license plates to see if people owe tickets. It’s like panning for gold, right?

Defendant: Exactly.

Judge: So you just randomly run plates until you find somebody who owes?

Defendant: That’s right.

Judge: This guy had more than what in tickets?

Defendant: The car has to be towed if they owe $350.01 or more.

Judge: So you find him, and he owes how much?

Defendant: $633.13.

Judge: Okay. So you tow the car. Where was it towed from?

Plaintiff: From my job. I went to work, left early, came out, and my car was gone. I pressed my alarm, hoping to hear it, but nothing.

Judge: And then you realized?

Plaintiff: My car was towed.

Judge: You had to pay the tickets?

Plaintiff: Yes. Paid at the DMV, then at the tow yard. When I got to my car, I saw scratches on the front left bumper.

Judge: You have pictures?

Plaintiff: Yes. If you need to see a clearer image, I have my phone.

Judge: Let’s see it.

(Plaintiff shows images)

Judge: That’s bad. Now, why had you had the insurance company do an inspection of your car?

Plaintiff: Because I had just gotten the car. They require a photo inspection.

Judge: So, coincidentally, they took pictures of it earlier that day?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: That’s bad for you, Defendant. Let’s hear your side.

Defendant: We towed the vehicle. He was parked by cement blocks. We towed it from the back. We opened the vehicle, put it in neutral.

Judge: Do you have video of this tow?

Defendant: No, but we have video of a similar tow showing we don’t touch any areas.

Judge: But he’s not saying your tow hook damaged the car. He’s saying your driver wasn’t careful pushing it away from the block, causing the damage. Do you have video proving otherwise?

Defendant: No, we don’t have video of that tow.

Judge: You were supposed to have a video, and it magically disappeared. There’s damage to the front bumper, which wasn’t there earlier that day. When do I rule against you and put you out of your misery?

Defendant: (Silent)

Judge: I like you, but it’s going to be $397.39 plus your court costs. Take care.
manipulation_techniques: Evasion, deflection, gaslighting, playing the victim,

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says the defendant’s 90 lb dog attacked her 9 lb Yorkie, Bella, and won’t pay the vet bills. But the defendant says the Yorkie was on her property, and the pooch stared her dog down. It’s the case of no Bella.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Ronda Marin, you are suing Galina Blatcher for $2,394.20 that you are out as a result of a dog bite when, according to you, her dog got loose and came out to bite your dog, correct? Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: So it was a Friday night, Memorial Day weekend. I was walking my dog like I normally do. We live in a community. As we were coming down her block past her house, my dog barks. Little dogs bark. All dogs bark at other dogs.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: That’s what my—my husband—my husband wouldn’t let me get a small dog because he’s worried that they’ll yap.

Judge: Your dog’s a yapper?

Plaintiff: She—well, yes. Outside, yes. Even at cars. So she’s a yapper, and she was just barking. And the next thing I know, Galina’s dog came barreling out from the backyard. There was no fence. There were no sidewalks, and I have pictures to show you that there were no sidewalks.

Judge: So you have to walk in the street because you can’t walk on anybody’s—where were you when the attack happened?

Plaintiff: In the street.

Judge: Where was your dog when the attack happened?

Plaintiff: With me, on a leash.

Judge: Where in the street did the scuffle happen?

Plaintiff: The first bite happened on her back. Then, as I was trying to pull her away, the second bite happened here, in her left groin. At that point, by the time I finally got my dog, she came running out and was able to get her dog and brought her dog from the street into her garage at that point.

Judge: So according to you, when she comes out, she comes to the street to get her dog?

Plaintiff: Absolutely.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Plaintiff: Because I was in the street. My phone was in the street. My sneakers were in the street.

Judge: Your sneakers flew off your feet?

Plaintiff: Well, everything got crazy because my dog got bit. The sound of a dog getting bit is not a pleasant one. So I was a little disturbed at that point. I just said, "I’m calling the police." And she said, "You should not be walking your dog down this street."

Judge: It’s—

Plaintiff: We can walk our dogs wherever we want. Now, my dog has had a previous altercation with the same dog.

Judge: With the same dog? How long ago?

Plaintiff: Two years ago, on the 15th. And I have the vet report from that time. I did not report it at that time because I was with my other dog walking, and it was an honest mistake. She opened up her garage, she had a dog with her, and the dog just ran. I didn’t press charges because my dog got bruised, but there were no issues at that point. I presented her with a bill at that time, and she paid it.

Judge: Is that accurate? Had your dog gotten out once before and attacked that dog?

Defendant: Not exactly. It’s first time it happened. And she gave me bill written down by hand. I paid her money.

Judge: How much was it?

Defendant: Like, I don’t remember. Close to $300.

Judge: Okay. But how did your big dog get out to bite her?

Defendant: Me and my dog, we were behind the house in the backyard. But immediately, when my dog felt her dog, she felt free and ran.

Judge: Wait, hold on one second. You and your dog were in the backyard?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Doing what?

Defendant: Sitting. She was on a leash. But when she heard this one, nobody can stop in a second. I was behind her. I thought, "Oh." And she already came down and waiting for me.

Judge: Your dog?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Where was she sitting?

Defendant: I have pictures.

Judge: Okay. I’ll see them. Come on up.

Defendant: Here. This is my property.

Judge: All right. Did Animal Control come?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Were you issued a summons?

Defendant: Yes, I paid $25.

Judge: How much?

Defendant: $25.

Judge: Okay. The problem is, your dog got loose. You admitted paying a bill one time before. You’ve paid her twice now. Why do that if it’s not your fault?

Defendant: Because I don’t want problems.

Judge: That’s not how it works. Pay the lady. Verdict for the plaintiff. $2,394.20.

Bailiff: Court is adjourned.

Judge: "You're a noncustodial parent, which means that she should receive the child support benefit and not you."

Defendant: "See, I'm—I'm honestly new to this whole thing. I'm not sure how it's supposed to work. I just know that, you know, I'm currently—if I don't have a job right now, I can—I can't take care of the kids when they come over on the weekends. I mean, I can barely afford—I mean, I'm barely affording to keep myself in that apartment."

**Judge:** All right, Mr. Willis, you're suing DJ Dre for $150 of a deposit because a party didn't happen. Tell me what happens here.

**Plaintiff:** Okay, so I was throwing his fraternity brother, which happens to be my actual best friend in real life.

**Judge:** In real life as opposed to fraternity life?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, I'm not in his fraternity. Okay, um, I was throwing a birthday party, a surprise birthday party for him, and I was referred to DJ Dre through one of their line sisters. And I, you know, I reached out to him and tried to book him for the service or actually booked him for the service. I booked him for the 27th.

**Judge:** 27th of?

**Plaintiff:** March.

**Judge:** And what day did you book him?

**Plaintiff:** For the 27th of March, I believe I sent the deposit March 14th.

**Judge:** Okay, go on.

**Plaintiff:** I went on to book him for the event. Due to finances, I had to cancel the event on the 22nd.

**Judge:** Why?

**Plaintiff:** Me and his fraternity brother's mom were the only ones paying for the event.

**Judge:** Cuz were other people—well, why are you throwing a party you can't afford? What was the plan originally?

**Plaintiff:** That everybody would contribute.

**Judge:** Other people?

**Plaintiff:** And then they didn't come through.

**Judge:** Oh, this is so sad. Does he know that we have all this litigation over what should have been his birthday party? Does he? It's like he must feel terrible.

**Plaintiff:** I tried. I tried to not tell him about it.

**Judge:** Well, he's going to know now, pal, because you're on national television. As it turns out, you changed your mind about the party, and then you tell—because of what you just said—and then you tell Dre that you want the money back. And what does Dre tell you?

**Plaintiff:** He tells me no, he doesn't do refunds.

**Judge:** Right. And then your answer to that is what?

**Plaintiff:** That's not what was said in the contract.

**Judge:** Okay. And what was said in the contract?

**Plaintiff:** So he sent me a note, and he sent me what I would be paying is for a deposit and the rest of the money and everything else that we cover, right? Um, under the deposit area, it doesn't say anything about non-refundable, refundable, none of that.

**Judge:** Okay, and let me hear from you, Dre. Why won’t you return the guy’s money?

**Defendant:** So, um, as I told him in the text messages, I don’t do refunds on deposits. Like, it’s kind of an industry standard for any industry that really does deposits.

**Judge:** Why? What’s the purpose of a deposit, Dre?

**Defendant:** So it's an insurance for us, honestly. Uh, we commit to whatever you want us to commit to, same with you committing to us. Then, um, yeah. So I’m turning down other gigs, any preparation work I got to do—

**Judge:** I mean, what do you think, Mr. Willis? Is the premise of a deposit to book you for the date?

**Plaintiff:** Right.

**Judge:** So what makes you think that you can put down a deposit and then just turn around and say, okay, you’re reserving that date for me, to the detriment of all other people and your own business, but you know what? I want it to be for free. So I changed my mind. In other words, the fact that it doesn’t say non-refundable—the default position is that it’s non-refundable. That’s the point of a deposit. You’re taking something off the market, whether it’s a car or a house or his services for a certain date. He’s taking it off the market on your behalf. And so, you know, then you change your mind. Why would you not lose the deposit?

**Judge:** Welcome back to the People's Court. The plaintiff says the defendant's simply an unscrupulous businessman who stole his money. The defendant certainly doesn't see it that way. Let's go back into the courtroom and see who's right.

**Judge:** On his claim against you, zero. And on your counterclaim against him, also zero. Good luck, gentlemen.

**Judge:** So there are no winners in this case in the People's Court. Both the plaintiff and the defendant have lost their suits.

**Judge:** That’s going to do it for us now, and we will see you in the next session of the People’s Court.

Judge: "Where does dad come in?"

Plaintiff: "I mean, he's rarely around. I mean, he's doing his little producing thing and stuff and meeting up with other women and stuff, you know. That's why I had this little charge, so I mean, that's what he's doing."

Judge: "It's a little charge?"

Plaintiff: "I mean, it's an assault charge, but I mean, it is what it is at this point. It already happened, so okay."

Judge: Whole parties, please use your right hand. Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff brought a car to the defendant for a recall problem, and when it came back, it was making ridiculous noise. But the defendant says he never even touched the engine, so the fact is, the car is a junker. It's the case of Hoop D No Can Do. Litigants have been sworn.

Judge: Sounds like Shamika Hewitt, you are suing Robert D. Gregorris’s dealership. All right, we've agreed not to mention that you are a franchisee of a major manufacturer of cars. You don't want their name mentioned, and we'll respect that. You’re suing his dealership for five thousand dollars for aggravation and money for a new car because, according to you, they broke your car. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: I purchased a vehicle February 1st from a private party.

Judge: From a person?

Plaintiff: Yeah, it was a dealer in Delaware.

Judge: A dealer. Okay. And then you drove back to New York?

Plaintiff: Right. Okay. Yeah. The steering wheel was shaking, so I took it to a mechanic.

Judge: Had you test-driven it beforehand?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: It was not shaking when you test-drove it, right?

Plaintiff: No. I had it for a couple of days. The man did tell me I had to change the brakes.

Judge: Who told you that?

Plaintiff: The person who sold it.

Judge: The person, yes. But the steering wheel hadn't been shaking when you bought the car? That was something that happened on the drive down?

Plaintiff: Right. Okay. Yeah. So then I took it to the mechanic when I got to New York.

Judge: And?

Plaintiff: He said I needed control arms and the wheel bearings. So I said okay. When he put it on a lift, he said the frame on the inside of the car was cracking. He looked something up and came back and said, "Did you know that these trucks had a recall on it?" I said no, I had only had it a couple of days. He said, "Yeah, it was about two years ago. They had a recall on it." Before he did the work, he said to have them fix the frame first.

Judge: So you called the dealer. You took it to them, and they fixed it. The recall was for what?

Plaintiff: The recall was for some rusting on the strut towers, where the shocks go into.

Judge: Okay, that's a recall. So he takes care of the repair. You take the car, and then what happens? Do you take it back to the first guy so that you can actually get the repair your car needed?

Plaintiff: No. When I picked it up, the car was barely moving.

Judge: What does barely moving mean?

Plaintiff: It was in four-wheel drive. The oil light was on. There was a loud knocking noise when the man brought it out to me.

Judge: And?

Plaintiff: I said, "What happened to the truck? It wasn’t like this when I brought it to you six days ago." He said, "Oh, I don’t know, I didn’t touch it." So I called inside. He went inside to tell them I could barely move the truck. They said they would send somebody outside. A man came outside, drove the car back and forth to get it out of four-wheel drive.

Judge: Why was it in four-wheel drive?

Plaintiff: I asked him that. He said, "I don’t know, I didn’t touch the car." So I said, "Okay, could somebody find the guy who did touch the car?"

Judge: Defendant, what happened that day?

Defendant: The vehicle was in four-wheel drive because there was a snowstorm that day. The body shop had to put the vehicle in four-wheel drive to move it.

Judge: So they performed the repair, and then she picked it up?

Defendant: Yes. She didn’t know how to return it to two-wheel drive.

Judge: Did somebody take it out of four-wheel drive for you?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then what was wrong with it?

Plaintiff: The oil light was on. The man who came out said I didn’t need oil, but the light kept flashing.

Judge: Defendant, was the oil light on?

Defendant: No, it was not.

Judge: You take your car to a repair shop. They fix one thing, but it comes out with another problem. Are they responsible?

(Audience members provide opinions.)

Judge: Plaintiff, did you take it to another mechanic afterward?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What did they say?

Plaintiff: They gave me this document.

Judge: This looks like a typed note, not an official repair invoice.

Defendant: She purchased this vehicle from an auction. She asked me to help return it. I found out it was sold "as is." The car had a salvage title from fifteen years ago.

Judge: Plaintiff, you bought a twenty-year-old car that turned out to be garbage. You have no evidence they ruined the engine. Verdict for the defendant.

Judge: "What do you do for a living?"

Defendant: "I don't work. I'll take care of her kid."

Judge: "So you're a stay-at-home mom?"

Defendant: "Mmm... And he’s 11."

Judge: "He's 11. He goes to school?"

Defendant: "He does."

Judge: "So what do you do during the day?"

Defendant: "Nothing."

Judge: "You don't want to work?"

Defendant: "Oh no."

Judge: "So you're just living off of his child support?"

Defendant: "I am, and we live with our mother."

Judge: "And you're proud of that as well?"

Defendant: "Well, we were living with him, and I was a stay-at-home mom. He made the income."

Judge: "Okay, but I mean, you can work now, right?"

Defendant: "I can, but—"

Judge: "So there's nobody stopping you. You can go get a job, right?"

Defendant: "I could, but I'm not going to. I rinse free, my food is free... I mean, my mom's a homeowner. We don't have to pay nothing."

Judge: All parties, please be seated.

Judge: Welcome to the People’s Court. This case is about whether the defendant illegally towed the plaintiff’s car and whether the plaintiff is entitled to compensation for the tow fee and radiator damage. Let's begin. Mr. Uden, according to you, you were the unfortunate victim of a wrongful tow that damaged your car. Is that correct?

Plaintiff: Yes, your Honor.

Judge: Where was your car parked?

Plaintiff: I park my car in the housing parking lot. My assigned number is 12.

Judge: And were you legitimately parked there?

Plaintiff: Yes, I pay the rent every year.

Judge: It’s not about paying the rent. Was the spot you parked in assigned to you?

Plaintiff: Yes, this is my parking space.

Judge: Mr. O’Grady, you were asked to tow the car because it was what?

Defendant: We were told it was illegally parked.

Judge: Why?

Defendant: The reason was not given to us. The contractor called us to tow the car.

Judge: Do you have proof that you were authorized to tow the car?

Defendant: Yes, your Honor. Here is the receipt from the housing authority. They stamp it when the tow is requested.

Judge: Is this a government housing project?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have been living there for 40 years.

Judge: So, the housing people asked you to tow the car, and you feel that you were towed inappropriately because you were in your assigned space?

Plaintiff: Yes, I was parked in my spot.

Judge: Did you ever talk to them about it?

Plaintiff: Yes, but they denied responsibility. They said it was my responsibility to check the number. I had the sticker with my plate number and parking number 12.

Judge: So, they are saying you weren’t in number 12?

Plaintiff: No, I was in the right spot. They did not check the windshield sticker.

Judge: Mr. O’Grady, do you know what space you towed him from?

Defendant: That’s between him and the housing authority.

Judge: Mr. Uden, what happened when you got your car back?

Plaintiff: The radiator was leaking. I took it to a garage, and they replaced it.

Judge: Do you have the receipt for the radiator repair?

Plaintiff: Yes, here it is.

Judge: That’s what you’re suing for, correct? The $415 for the radiator and the tow fee?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Mr. O’Grady, if you damaged the radiator, you would be responsible for replacing it. How do you respond?

Defendant: Towing does not normally damage a radiator. I provided a video showing how we tow vehicles properly.

Judge: Mr. Uden, do you have evidence that the towing caused the damage?

Plaintiff: The car was not leaking before. After the tow, it started leaking.

Judge: But do you have documentation from the mechanic stating that the tow caused the damage?

Plaintiff: No, they did not give me anything specific.

Judge: Mr. O’Grady, how do you tow cars?

Defendant: We use a standard wrecker with a front lift and install dollies on the back wheels.

Judge: Where is the radiator in the car?

Defendant: In the front.

Judge: Do you have any additional evidence linking the tow to the radiator damage?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: What year is your car?

Plaintiff: 1997 Toyota 4Runner.

Judge: That’s an old car. I have to consider whether the radiator failure was due to age rather than towing. Also, you are suing the wrong person. Mr. O’Grady was following orders from the housing authority. If they ordered the tow incorrectly, your issue is with them.

Judge: My verdict in this case is for the defendant.

Bailiff: All parties, please raise your right hands. Be seated. Come to order, please. Litigants have been sworn, Your Honor.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Mark Minsky, you are suing James. You've asked us not to refer to your last name or the salon's name, and we will respect that. You're suing him as owner of the salon for $315, a replacement cost for eyeglasses that you say were stolen from the salon. Talk to me. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Okay, so I went there to have my haircut back on Thursday, March 24th, in the evening. And I sat down in the stylist's chair. Uh, there was no space to put my glasses on her personal shelf, so there was a Parson table to my left, and I reached out, and I took them off and placed them within arm’s reach on this table to my left. When the haircut was complete, I turned to my left to pick up the glasses. They were gone.

Judge: How far away from your body were your glasses?

Plaintiff: Maybe 3 feet. Arm’s reach.

Judge: Right. So wouldn’t you see somebody if somebody had taken your glasses?

Plaintiff: I did not. I guess my peripheral vision is not the best.

Judge: So at that point?

Plaintiff: I mentioned it to the stylist. She had some employees, I presume some hair washers as I recall, come and help me look. We looked in a variety of—

Judge: How are you looking? Because if you have no glasses on, are you not very—there is nothing worse than when I lose my glasses. I need to enlist an army to help me because if—without—if I don’t have them, I can’t find them. So it’s just a self-fulfilling—

Plaintiff: Yes, very difficult, to say the least. So we looked for quite a while, you know, probably over an hour. And as you just pointed out, I do need my glasses to see. My vision is actually 20 over 150 in one eye, 20 over 300 in the other.

Judge: Right, but why are you suing the salon? What did the salon do? You lost your glasses. Why—why is it responsible for you losing your glasses?

Plaintiff: Somebody removed them from where I had placed them.

Judge: Why is the salon responsible? Let’s assume somebody did take them. Who’s the somebody? Why is the salon responsible?

Plaintiff: Because I walked—I—it happened there. I walked in there. I placed it, you know, within—

Judge: What did they do wrong? Normally, when somebody has to pay you for something, they have to have done something wrong. So what did they do wrong? Do you have a—do you have a camera in there?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Did you at one point tell him that you had a camera?

Defendant: It was a salon somebody else owned. I didn’t—

Judge: Did you at one point tell him that you had a camera going?

Defendant: I never said that, no.

Judge: Okay. According to you, somebody told you that?

Plaintiff: Yes, he has a business partner, and he told me that there was a camera. He was going to review it, and when he did, he calls me and tells me that the videotape showed I came in without glasses.

Judge: Okay. And I asked—come on out. Who are the ladies who are there? Are they witnesses? ‘Cause one of them is chicken-necking, so I think she—

Defendant: This is Nancy, who interacted the whole night with him.

Judge: Okay. Did you guys ever see a camera, like see the—see the tape? Was there a tape?

Defendant: No, there was—

Judge: Was he just saying that to him to get him off?

Defendant: He was just saying it.

Judge: But this is very interesting—kind of rude.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: Right. Because you're saying the glasses were stolen. If you’re saying you came in without them, then you’re calling him a liar.

Defendant: I never said that to him.

Plaintiff: His partner did.

Judge: His partner did. But his partner's not the one who’s being sued.

Plaintiff: Right, but his partner said it in the course of handling it for him.

Judge: Okay, so why would his partner say that?

Plaintiff: To deflect the situation.

Judge: Okay, but you’re assuming that.

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Do you have anything beyond that? Do you have a police report?

Plaintiff: I did file a police report.

Judge: Okay. And?

Plaintiff: Nothing came of it.

Judge: Right. Because what’s a police officer gonna do? Say, "Hey, everybody in the salon, empty your pockets?" That’s not how it works.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: Right. I mean, unless somebody was caught on camera—which there is no camera—you don’t have proof that somebody stole it.

Plaintiff: I understand.

Judge: And you’re suing the salon, but there’s no legal theory under which the salon owes you $315.

Plaintiff: I understand.

Judge: Verdict for the defendant.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Leia Franklin, you are suing James Waller for $5,000. You say you're actually out more than that because, according to you, he sold you a lemon. What happened here?

Plaintiff: I was recommended to him, and, you know, because I knew him, I went to him. I told him about a situation I was having with my previous car, and he told me he had two cars available. I said okay, how much do you want for them? He said one was $1,400 and the other—

Judge: Now, are these cars that he owned, or did he take you to a wholesaler? What happened there?

Plaintiff: He said that he was the dealer, that they were his cars, and that he was selling them. He said he was going to give me a good price because going through him would be a whole lot cheaper.

Judge: Okay, so you picked out your car?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And what did you pick out?

Plaintiff: A 2015 Honda Accord Hybrid for $1,400.

Judge: Okay. And when you met him, what happened?

Plaintiff: The first car he showed me, he said it had a $50 pin missing from the clutch. So I said, "Okay, no, I won’t take this one." Then I asked, "What’s wrong with the hybrid?" He said, "Nothing’s wrong with it. It’s perfectly fine. It just needs a regular tune-up and stuff like that."

Judge: Did you have a mechanic come and look at it to make sure that it was okay?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: So you didn’t get it inspected before purchasing?

Plaintiff: He had a mechanic on—

Judge: No, no. I don’t want to know about his mechanic. I’m asking, did you, the one buying the car, have a mechanic check it?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Go on.

Plaintiff: I looked at the car. I started it up. It needed gas. And then I said, "Are you sure it’s okay?" He said, "Yes, nothing’s wrong with the car." He said, "If anything’s wrong with it, I’ll fix it."

Judge: Did he put that in writing, that warranty you just mentioned?

Plaintiff: No, he didn’t.

Judge: Because this is a 13-year-old car. So if somebody says, "If anything’s wrong with it, I’ll fix it," that’s really important to be able to prove.

(To Defendant) Did you tell her that if anything was wrong with the 2015 Accord, you would pay to fix it?

Defendant: No, I did not.

Judge: Yeah, watch out. Because when you say something like that, you better be able to prove it, because that kind of amazing warranty on a used car doesn’t usually happen.

(To Plaintiff) So, you took the car home. When did you start having problems?

Plaintiff: To be honest with you, after I put gas in it. I drove it maybe 20 minutes. I told him, "I really hope I didn’t just buy a messed-up car." He said, "No, the car is fine." Then he asked, "What kind of gas did you put in?" I said, "89."

Judge: And what did he say?

Plaintiff: He said, "That’s what made the check engine light come on."

Judge: Where did you get the idea that putting in the wrong octane gas can cause a check engine light to come on?

Defendant: From mechanics, ma’am. From having previous cars and putting bad gas in my own cars.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Plaintiff: I called him, but we were both on the parkway, leaving from Queens back to Long Island, so he didn’t answer. When I got home, he called me back and said, "It’s because you put 89 in it."

Judge: And then what?

Plaintiff: He told me to "drive it out." So I drove the gas out and put in 93, but the check engine light was still on.

Judge: How many days later was this?

Plaintiff: Maybe a day and a half.

Judge: And then?

Plaintiff: I called him and told him the check engine light didn’t go off.

Judge: When did you finally take it to a mechanic?

Plaintiff: Maybe that following Wednesday.

Judge: How long after purchasing the car?

Plaintiff: Three or four days.

Judge: And what did the mechanic tell you?

Plaintiff: He gave me a report and told me I shouldn’t have bought this car.

Judge: Let me see what the mechanic gave you.

(Plaintiff hands over documents.)

Judge: And this bill of sale—when was it prepared?

Defendant: More than a week after she got the vehicle. And actually, I just assisted her in acquiring a vehicle. I took her to A1 Auto Sales.

Judge: That’s not you?

Defendant: No, I’m an independent contractor under A1.

Judge: How did you make money on the $1,400?

Defendant: I didn’t make any money on her because I knew her.

Judge: Why didn’t you make money?

Defendant: She bought a 13-year-old car, didn’t get it checked out, and now wants a refund.

Judge: Why are you signing a bill of sale a week later if you had problems in the first three days?

Plaintiff: Because he told me—

Judge: No, no. Why?

Plaintiff: He said—

Judge: The default position is as-is for a used car.

Plaintiff: But the mileage was wrong!

Judge: Prove that.

(Plaintiff hands over another document.)

Judge: This doesn’t prove mileage fraud. My verdict is for the defendant.

(Bangs gavel.)

Defendant: "There was just the doubts... It was just the cheating..."
Judge: "Mr. Edwards, you say you brought a witness today."
Defendant: "Yes."
Judge: "I'd like to hear from that witness."
Defendant: "Jerome, will you please escort her into the courtroom? She's only been here since around February. She's a nobody."
Plaintiff: "I'm going to bring you up to the witness stand next to the judge. 'Cause you're sleeping with her, too."
Defendant: "That's what you think."

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says the defendant spilled a drink on his laptop and ruined it. But the defendant says the laptop was hidden, so it’s his problem. It's the case of La Dancing.

Judge: Brian O'Gorman, you are suing your former friend Casey for $755, the cost to repair a laptop that was damaged as a result of what you say is her negligence. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: Well, for New Year's Eve, I organized a little get-together of our close friends. There were about 15 of us total. We got four hotel rooms, so no one had to drive. We arrived around 6:00 PM. My roommates and I dropped off our baggage and then brought food up to the girls’ room. We had all made food to eat.

Judge: And she's one of your good friends who was renting another room?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How long have you two known each other?

Plaintiff: About seven years.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Plaintiff: After eating, we had a couple of drinks, then went back downstairs to shower and get ready for the night. While I was downstairs, my friend Chris and I discussed where to put our belongings so they wouldn't be in anyone's way. We didn't want anyone going through our bags or anything. Then we discussed the laptop. I didn’t want anything to happen to it, so Chris suggested we put it up high, out of the way.

Judge: Where exactly did you put it?

Plaintiff: On top of the armoire.

Judge: How tall is the armoire?

Plaintiff: About 5'10".

Judge: Were you trying to hide it, or just keep it safe?

Plaintiff: Just wanted it out of everyone’s way. I didn’t want anyone messing with it.

Judge: Was it open or closed?

Plaintiff: It was open because it was playing music.

Judge: So it was open at a 90-degree angle?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then what happened?

Plaintiff: Later, after we got ready, the girls came down. About 40 minutes later, Casey put her drink up there, and it spilled over onto my laptop. Another friend quickly grabbed the laptop, took it to the bathroom, and tried drying it with a towel and a blow dryer. Then we put the laptop away, and I told Casey, “It’s New Year’s Eve, let’s just enjoy the night.”

Judge: What was her reaction?

Plaintiff: She kept apologizing.

Judge: Was she drunk?

Plaintiff: None of us were drunk. It was still early in the night.

Defendant: Like he said, there were about 15 of us. I had my first mixed drink in my hand, and people wanted to take pictures. I didn’t want alcohol in my pictures because they would probably go on Facebook, and I wanted to be professional.

Judge: You’re 21?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Everyone in the room was 21?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Go on.

Defendant: I was trying to do the responsible thing. I didn’t want alcohol in my pictures. So, I looked around for a place to put my drink and saw the dresser. I had no idea his laptop was up there.

Judge: How tall was the dresser?

Defendant: Probably about twice my size. I’m 5'1".

Judge: You’re saying you had to stand on your tiptoes?

Defendant: Yes, I was in high heels.

Judge: If you had to stretch to put your drink there, why choose that spot?

Defendant: It seemed like the safest place where no one would knock it over.

Judge: Did you see his open laptop?

Defendant: No, I didn’t see it. I had no idea it was there.

Judge: But it was playing music, and it was open at 90 degrees. Wouldn't you have noticed it if you looked?

Defendant: I just didn’t see it.

Judge: So, you admit you put your drink up there, and it spilled?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: You understand that’s negligence, right?

Defendant: I mean, I don’t think I’m 100% responsible. He knew the risks of having an open laptop at a party where people are drinking.

Judge: Did you offer to pay?

Defendant: I offered to pay half. I said I could give him $500.

Plaintiff: Yes, but then she changed her mind and took back the offer.

Defendant: I don’t have a job, so I said I could pay when I got one in the summer.

Judge: Do you have a picture of the armoire?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: [Looking at the photo] How could you not see the laptop? It’s clearly visible. It’s your fault, and I’m ordering you to pay the full $755 plus tax and court costs.

Judge: That’s my verdict. Good luck, folks.

Judge: All parties please raise your right hand. Be seated and come to order. Please. Thank you.

Judge: Tian, you’ve asked us not to use your last name?

Plaintiff: Yes, please.

Judge: Okay, Tian. You’re suing Francis Pedford Johnson, your former landlord, for $2,800 for not returning your security deposit from back when?

Plaintiff: 2010.

Judge: 2010. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Well, I knew Francis for a couple of years, we worked together, and when I was looking to move into a new apartment, she told me she had a multi-family home. I moved into her apartment, I lived there five years. It was an easy agreement, month to month. I gave her two months' security deposit.

Judge: How much did you give her?

Plaintiff: $2,800.

Judge: That was the security deposit? You gave her $2,800 plus the first month's rent?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: And all she asked is that I live there at least a year and give her two months' notice when I was vacating. In August, I told her I was looking to relocate to Maryland, and I would know for sure and give her the two months that she asked for. In October, I gave her—

Judge: So you were roommates, or it was a separate entrance?

Plaintiff: She has a multi-family home. I was just renting one of her units.

Judge: Got it.

Plaintiff: I gave her my official notice in October that I would be moving in December. December came, and I moved out at the end of February.

Judge: Did you pay rent in October, November, and December?

Plaintiff: No. When I gave her my notice in October, she asked me if I was going to live out my deposit. I told her I had not planned to, but I would if she wanted.

Judge: Good idea.

Plaintiff: Well, I hadn’t planned on it. She brought it up, suggested it. I said I could do that. So, I didn’t pay rent in October.

Judge: Then October 10th she called you and said?

Plaintiff: She said, "I didn’t get your rent check for the month." And I said, "I’m living it out like you requested." And she’s like, "Oh no, no, you know, you can’t do that. I need the money." And I said, "Okay." I said, "Well, I’ve already allocated the rent funds for October to my moving expenses."

Judge: I don’t know what you’re saying. Did you pay October? Yes or no.

Plaintiff: No, I did not pay.

Judge: Did you pay November?

Plaintiff: No—I'm sorry, I did pay October.

Judge: Did you?

Plaintiff: I did not pay November.

Judge: This isn’t hard. You had to know I was going to ask these questions.

Plaintiff: Apologies. You did pay October, you didn’t pay November?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: And did you pay December?

Plaintiff: I gave her notice in October. I had already paid rent.

Judge: You’re confusing me because you’re suing for the entire security deposit when you’re telling me point-blank that you didn’t pay November.

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: So why aren’t you just suing for $1,300?

Plaintiff: Because she flat-out just didn’t have it. She asked for more time, I gave it to her, and she took that as an opportunity to not pay me.

Judge: Did she ever give you any inkling that she wasn’t going to pay you?

Plaintiff: No, she just kept saying she couldn’t figure it out. First, she didn’t have it, then she asked for more time, then she said she wanted to figure it out.

Judge: How long does it take? Two years to figure out?

Defendant: The main reason is that Tian, when she left, she had her father, she had two other guys—well, she had about five people helping her move. And when she left, she left a huge air conditioner in the living room window, a small one in the bedroom window, and a huge—48 inches or 50 inches—television set on the bedroom floor.

Judge: What reason did she give you for not taking them?

Defendant: She said she told a couple of the young men they could have them and to contact me, but she never told me this. I had no idea.

Judge: Did they contact you to try to pick it up?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Did anybody come pick up the ACs and the TV?

Defendant: Finally.

Judge: What’s "finally"?

Defendant: February.

Judge: And she moved out when?

Defendant: The end of December.

Judge: So, within 30-45 days, somebody had picked up the items?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Did you re-rent the place in January or February?

Defendant: No, I couldn’t rent it with that stuff in there.

Judge: You could have. You could have paid someone $50 to take the TV out. At some point, you have to hold on for a certain amount of days. Typically, judges require landlords to wait 30 days. And within 30 days, she removed it. So, why are you still holding onto $1,300?

Defendant: There were other damages. She broke a window.

Judge: Did you repair the window?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: What date?

Defendant: It's recent.

Judge: So, you waited two years to fix the window?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: How much did it cost?

Defendant: $70.

Judge: Are there any other reasons for keeping the $1,300?

Defendant: She put holes in the walls.

Judge: Did she patch them?

Defendant: Yes, but the paint didn’t match.

Judge: The paint you gave her?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then you should’ve provided the right paint. You are not entitled to keep $1,300 for a $70 repair and a TV that was picked up in 30 days. My ruling is for the Plaintiff for $1,230.

Judge: Okay, so how much money do you make?
Defendant: Not a lot. 15 bucks an hour. So I make a couple of thousand a month.
Plaintiff: If I may, Your Honor, in case he doesn't volunteer it, he has just recently got a settlement for a lawsuit and that's the main reason. At $15 now, I wouldn't have brought him to court asking for child support.
Judge: Oh, now it makes sense. Now it makes sense.

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Thomas Luro. He says the defendant backed his giant SUV out of a parking spot and plowed right into him in his 2019 Toyota Corolla. The defendant had promised to pay for the damages and then has dodged him ever since, claiming he's only 19 years old and broke. Well, sorry buddy, but that's so not his problem. He's suing for $1,405—the cost to repair his car.

This is the defendant, Dakota Rigs. He says he was driving his grandmother’s Hyundai Santa Fe and lightly tapped the plaintiff’s Toyota. The plaintiff is trying to take advantage of him because he’s young and is inflating the damage so he can get as much money as possible. Well, he might just be a kid working at Chipotle about to go into the Marines, but there’s no way a tiny scratch on a car costs over $1,400 to fix, and he thinks the judge will agree. He’s accused of a backup crackup.

All parties, please raise your right hands.

Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case in the docket: the plaintiff says the defendant backed his SUV into his brand-new Toyota. But the defendant says he barely tapped the guy’s car, so get real. It’s the case of you asked for it, you got it.

Thank you, Douglas.

Okay, Thomas Luto, you’re suing Dakota Rigs for $1,455—an estimate to fix a fender of your Corolla—when the defendant, who was driving a 2012 Hyundai Santa Fe… which is what, a big old SUV?

Plaintiff: Big old SUV.

Judge: Backed right out of his spot and hit you, according to you?

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: Okay, tell me how it happened. You’re going down the parking lot—why don’t you come over here, pick a car, be you, be him. Come on over here.

Plaintiff: Okay.

Judge: This is—he’s parked here? Got it. Then take another car and make it you.

Plaintiff: I’m over here.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Stopped. Looked to park. Okay.

Judge: Mm-hmm.

Plaintiff: Out of nowhere, this car starts backing up. Boom.

Judge: Boom. Okay.

Defendant: Right.

Judge: What happened? You didn’t see him?

Defendant: He was right in my blind spot, ma’am.

Judge: He was?

Defendant: I was backing out and I didn’t notice any cars. I looked both ways, and then little did I know—thud.

Judge: Yeah.

Defendant: And I turned around.

Judge: What’s your defense?

Defendant: I’m sorry?

Judge: What’s your defense?

Defendant: My defense is that the car lightly tapped each other, and I don’t feel that—I do feel that I do need to pay him, yes.

Judge: Mm-hmm.

Defendant: Although—

Judge: You don’t think it’s entirely your fault because it was your blind spot?

Defendant: It is not entirely my fault because it is my blind spot, yes.

Judge: Where’d you get that idea that your blind spot is someone else’s fault?

Defendant: I blame the blind spot.

Judge: Well, the blind spot better have some cash! It’s your blind spot. Okay? You backed out, and you hit somebody. It’s an accident. Now, you feel that he’s milking it and that the amount he’s asking is too high. Have you—how old are you?

Defendant: I’m 19.

Judge: Okay. Have you ever had body damage on your car that you’ve had to pay for?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay. So, but the damage was a lot more?

Defendant: How much damage was it?

Judge: Yeah.

Defendant: It was the whole engine. The whole front end was just—

Judge: So it was a big accident?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Was it yours? Was it your accident?

Defendant: It was not considered my fault.

Judge: No? How?

Defendant: Not considered my fault.

Judge: What do you mean?

Defendant: The insurance company didn’t consider it my fault because the lady was not considered believable.

Judge: My point originally—I started off asking that to see if you understood how expensive bodywork is. But then I found out about this whole other accident.

Defendant: Mm-hmm.

Judge: But in any event, do you have pictures of the damage?

Plaintiff: I don’t.

Judge: You already got it fixed and you don’t have pictures to show me?

Plaintiff: The body shop has the pictures.

Judge: Well, okay, let’s think this through a moment. Who are the pictures for? I dare say they’re for me. This is exactly what you took the pictures for. This lady in the black dress. What are they doing—warming someone’s manila folder at a body shop? Are you crazy? Come on! Can a Toyota Corolla bumper cost $1,400?

Defendant: Yeah. That could definitely happen.

Judge: Yeah.

Defendant: That honestly can.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: I did bring the invoices, which detail all the work.

Judge: Show me the invoice.

Plaintiff: Have you taken your car there for work before?

Defendant: My daughter has.

Judge: Replace the left fender… Here’s a credit card receipt. And it costs $1,405, which is what you’re suing for. Now, at some point, you guys had negotiated where you were going to pay how much?

Defendant: He threw me the estimate of $1,800, so I was trying to figure out if I could maybe do something cheaper because I’m only 19 and—

Judge: Because you’re only what?

Defendant: I’m only 19 years old and I can only make so much money, Your Honor.

Judge: Okay, so he takes it there, and it’s $1,405 instead of—where did the figure $1,800 come from?

Defendant: It was the original estimate.

Judge: Which was from who?

Defendant: The same body shop.

Judge: And then they decided they were able to do it for $1,405?

Defendant: Right. He was able to mix the paint in a cheap way.

Judge: So then you tell him, "Good news, it’s $1,405," and then he says what?

Plaintiff: He said "okay," basically, in a text.

Judge: Okay. You tell him, "I’ll tell you what, if you pay upfront, I’ll give you a discount, you just pay me $1,100, I’ll foot the rest." And you say?

Defendant: I can’t do that. I have to go with our original plan.

Judge: Which was?

Defendant: $300 a month.

Judge: And then what happened?

Defendant: I was working overtime.

Judge: Well, now you’re paying the full $1,405. Verdict for the plaintiff.
manipulation_techniques: minimization, playing the victim, emotional appeal, evasion

dialogue:
