Judge: Okay, you're suing Ashley Packard for $3,227 in rent and utilities because, according to you, she violated a stipulation that the two of you had entered into in landlord-tenant court. All right, you own a piece of property that is a salon?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And when did you start renting it?

Plaintiff: In December.

Judge: So how long were you there in total?

Defendant: A year and a half.

Judge: Okay. And what went wrong?

Plaintiff: The reason we're here is because she did not meet the stipulations.

Judge: Right. How did you end up in landlord-tenant court? What was the first thing that went wrong in this tenancy?

Plaintiff: The rent was not paid for July and August.

Judge: Okay, so July and August of what year?

Plaintiff: 2018.

Judge: Did you pay July and August?

Defendant: No, that's because I received a notice to quit.

Judge: Okay. Were you in the middle of a lease?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: All right, so she stops paying rent, and why did you give her a notice to quit? Had you received any complaints or anything?

Plaintiff: The reason was that she was constantly late with rent. Also, the electricity had to be paid at that time. Sometimes she would pay it at the same time, sometimes later. But there were other reasons. I spoke to her because she brought in people to do acrylic nails. The acrylic nails were producing a very bad offensive odor, which traveled. The lady upstairs had commented on it, and I spoke with her. She said that the ones that were doing the nails were going to be bringing in a ventilation system. That stuff never works.

Judge: All right. Anyway, so what was the deal with the people who you hired to do nails?

Defendant: Let me quote you: they were Spanish and sometimes could be a bit mouthy. But the plaintiff was the one who was being disruptive to our business. You know, those Spanish people, they are quite mouthy. You know, those Latinos, they can be a bit mouthy. So yes, my girls who were working for me or with me—I should say because they rented their spots—they could be a little… They just stood their ground with what they knew was right.

Judge: Okay. But what was it that they were standing their ground about? Would she come in person and complain, or was it the tenant upstairs coming down?

Defendant: Gina was trying to get a hold of me. One day, I was in the middle of an updo class at another salon. When I got out of class, I heard all these voice messages from my co-workers telling me that she came in, she was screaming at them to stop doing what they were doing, to call me. And when they told her that I was at an updo class, they said that she threw down her purse on the floor, started snooping through my drawers in my station, and started going through the salon. And they said—

Judge: Did they video her?

Defendant: They didn't video her, but this is what happened.

Judge: In this day and age, where basically everybody videos everybody all the time, there would be a video.

Defendant: They were in the middle of doing nails. They had clients sitting in their chairs. It was just overall very unprofessional.

Judge: All right. So there's no rent paid in July. There's no rent paid in August. You file a notice of eviction. You end up in landlord-tenant court. So there is a stipulation entered into that the defendant—that would be you—agrees to pay $1,665.28 no later than September 5th. Did you make that payment on September 5th?

Defendant: I did, and I have the proof.

Judge: How did you make the payment on September 5th?

Defendant: Check.

Judge: Did you mail it, or what did you do?

Defendant: I actually drove to her house and put the check in her mailbox.

Judge: So, the picture you have is you putting the check in her mailbox?

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: Okay. Is that your mailbox?

Plaintiff: Yes, it is.

Judge: And the picture is dated September 5th at 10:00 at night. Technically, she complied. So you don't see it until September 6th, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And you deposited it on September 6th. So that was one of the things you said she didn’t comply with, but you cannot prove that she didn’t comply with it.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: So, the next thing she was supposed to do: the defendant agrees to remove all belongings, leave the premises broom clean, and return any and all keys to the plaintiff upon vacating. Any items left behind will be deemed abandoned. According to you, she didn’t do that?

Plaintiff: She left it a mess.

Judge: Tell me about it.

Plaintiff: There was a station left, a chair left outside, garbage left, alcohol, clutter, nail polish, a sink on the landing…

Judge: It was so simple. So, so simple. All you had to do was not leave garbage behind. Verdict for the plaintiff: $3,220.74. Good luck.

Judge:
Owner, the defendant has filed a countersuit for $1,500 for a wrongful arrest and harassment. All parties, please raise your right hand. Be seated. Come to order, please. Litigants have been sworn in. Thank you, Douglas. Welcome in. Okay, everyone's asked not to mention company names or last names. Ron, you're suing Sierra for $5,000 that you say is owed to you because she extended a car rental and damaged the car?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes ma'am, and put me in a position where I couldn't make money off the car.

Judge:
You are counterclaiming against him $1,500 for harassment and wrongful arrest. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Ron):
I rented to her previously, some months earlier, and she...

Judge:
What did you do for a living?

Plaintiff (Ron):
I rent cars. I rent cars and I have a party bus as well.

Judge:
Are they cars that you own?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes ma'am.

Judge:
Do you have a business doing this?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes ma'am.

Judge:
Do you have an office where you do it out of? Do you advertise, or do you just go word of mouth?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Word of mouth, um, business cards, and I have...

Judge:
How many cars do you own?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Right now it's just two.

Judge:
What about when this happened?

Plaintiff (Ron):
When that happened, it was three.

Judge:
Okay. She is someone who had rented from you before?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes ma'am.

Judge:
And how long were you renting to her for?

Plaintiff (Ron):
The original date was for one day and she told me she was going to come back and pay me some more for... um... I think she said she wanted to keep it a little longer. I think a week maybe.

Judge:
And after the day passed, what happened?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Okay, now hold on. What was it you rented to her?

Plaintiff (Ron):
A 2013 BMW 535.

Judge:
And how much were you charging her?

Plaintiff (Ron):
$80 a day.

Judge:
How much?

Plaintiff (Ron):
$80 a day.

Judge:
Is that competitive? Is that a good rate, or is it high or low?

Plaintiff (Ron):
It was a desperate situation. I needed a vehicle at the moment.

Judge:
And you couldn't go to like Enterprise and rent a cheap car?

Plaintiff (Ron):
No, because my name is actually messed up with Enterprise due to a situation with my sister not returning a vehicle. So, until I paid them, I exhausted all the other rental car places.

Judge:
When you went to the gentleman who does it in the alley, is that it? Like, how does this work?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Kind of, sort of. You could say it like that because actual Enterprise... I'm on the do-not-rent list until I pay them.

Judge:
Do not rent list?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Okay.

Judge:
What about Hertz or Avis or National or Thrifty?

Plaintiff (Ron):
No, because the credit card that I use with Enterprise is affiliated with that, so I have to clear up the money on the credit card, and they don’t accept... so he doesn’t take credit cards.

Judge:
No?

Plaintiff (Ron):
It’s just cash.

Judge:
So, you just give him cash?

Plaintiff (Ron):
How much?

Plaintiff (Ron):
I gave him $250 as a deposit.

Judge:
Okay. So, she gave you $250 plus $80?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes ma’am.

Judge:
Okay, and then what happens?

Defendant (Sierra):
I actually met him at a gas station, which is where he conducts his business.

Judge:
Right on in Queens, and I met him at the bail bonds office, which is how I got his business card. So, that's where he goes around giving people stuff so that they can rent vehicles.

Defendant (Sierra):
So, he’s providing a service, right?

Judge:
Yes.

Defendant (Sierra):
There you go. He can make the money, and he's providing a service that apparently you can't get elsewhere, so what the heck.

Judge:
Exactly, which is why I chose to use him. So, July 31st, now I called him. He said that he did have a vehicle, which was the 2013 BMW. I said, okay, I need it for one day, and I let him know when I got to the gas station with my then boyfriend. I let him know that the rental... I wanted to keep it for longer, but as of right now, I’m paying for one day and tomorrow when I return with the vehicle, which would have been August 1st, I’m going to have the rest of the money to compensate whether it be two days, three days, or four the week.

Defendant (Sierra):
No, what happened? It didn’t happen like that. Instead of like that, I’m going to tell you right now...

Judge:
Monday, when I came back with the car, I called him and told him that I was running late with the vehicle. I would bring it to him Tuesday morning. He okayed it and said you just have to pay for Tuesday and everything was in communication. Everything was fine.

Judge:
Tuesday now, when I called him to return the vehicle, I didn’t get a response.

Defendant (Sierra):
Now, being that I have to drop it to him back at the gas station, if I would have left the vehicle there, that would have been an issue. So now, when he didn’t answer his phone on Tuesday, it’s like now I have no choice but to still have the car, and I’m still going to have to pay for it because I have the car.

Judge:
And what happened on Wednesday?

Defendant (Sierra):
Wednesday, I spoke to him again, and I told him that I was going to extend the car. He said for how long, and I told him like three days tops.

Defendant (Sierra):
Wednesday I was at the bank. I spoke to him while I was in the bank, and I said, I’m at the bank right now, and I’m going to call you and bring you the money. He said okay, no problem. That was at about 11:15ish. So after that took place, my sister called me in an emergency and said she needed me to drive her home.

Judge:
Where?

Defendant (Sierra):
Texas.

Judge:
What? You need a ride to Texas?

Defendant (Sierra):
Yes.

Judge:
Why would you... you think that was okay?

Defendant (Sierra):
No, not with his vehicle. Not in his vehicle.

Judge:
No?

Defendant (Sierra):
She had her own car.

Judge:
You didn’t say all of a sudden, I have to go to Texas?

Defendant (Sierra):
No, she knew about the vehicle.

Judge:
And I also called him on Wednesday and left a message. I let him know, and I told him that because my boyfriend went with me to pick up the vehicle, he saw how he looked, and I felt that it would be okay for him to return it because I had to leave in an emergency.

Judge:
So you left the car in your boyfriend’s care?

Defendant (Sierra):
Yes.

Judge:
To be returned the next day?

Defendant (Sierra):
Yes.

Judge:
What did your boyfriend do? Did he return the car?

Defendant (Sierra):
Absolutely not, which is why we’re here.

Judge:
So, how do you feel about this?

Defendant (Sierra):
The whole thing feels like harassment. And, you know, I was put in a position where I was under emergency circumstances.

Judge:
And you got arrested after this?

Defendant (Sierra):
Yes.

Judge:
When?

Defendant (Sierra):
It was a few days after the incident where I left the car to be returned. I received a call and said the car was stolen, so I got arrested.

Plaintiff (Ron):
It wasn’t stolen. It was just sitting there for a while, and I was trying to get in touch with her.

Judge:
What do you want for all of this?

Defendant (Sierra):
I want the harassment to stop and to be compensated for wrongful arrest.

Judge:
Okay, we'll look at the evidence.    Judge:
Alright, so here's the deal. You’re saying you were wrongfully arrested and harassed?

Defendant (Sierra):
Yes, I believe I was. He called the police, said the car was stolen, and I got arrested in the middle of doing my hair at the salon. It was embarrassing, and completely unnecessary.

Plaintiff (Ron):
She never returned the car, and when I tried to reach her, she wouldn't answer. I had no choice but to call the cops to report it. It was a stolen vehicle at that point because I couldn't get in touch with her.

Judge:
So, you're saying she rented the car and then just stopped communicating with you?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes, exactly. I had been trying to get in touch with her for days and nothing. She wasn’t picking up the phone, and I didn't know where the car was.

Defendant (Sierra):
That’s not true. I told him I needed more time, and I was planning to return it. I just needed more time, and I let him know. It was never meant to be some big issue. I was going through things, and it wasn’t like I was just ignoring him.

Judge:
Alright. So it’s your claim that there was a lack of communication that led to this situation?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes. And also, the car was damaged when I got it back, which is why I'm asking for compensation.

Defendant (Sierra):
I didn't damage the car. That's an exaggeration. It wasn't perfect when I got it, but it wasn’t damaged to the extent that he’s claiming.

Judge:
Okay, let's talk about the damage. Ron, what kind of damage are you talking about?

Plaintiff (Ron):
The bumper was scratched up, and there were dents. It wasn’t in the condition I rented it out to her. And on top of that, I lost income because I couldn’t rent it out to anyone else while it was with her.

Judge:
Sierra, how do you respond to that?

Defendant (Sierra):
I didn't damage the car. I took care of it. If anything happened to it, it happened when it was sitting there for days while I was trying to get in touch with him. And I wasn't driving it around the way he's saying.

Judge:
Do you have any proof of this damage, Ron?

Plaintiff (Ron):
I have photos. I took pictures when I got the car back.

Judge:
Can you provide those photos, please?

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes, Your Honor. Here they are.

Defendant (Sierra):
That doesn’t show the real condition of the car when I got it. I don’t believe those photos are accurate.

Judge:
Okay, I’ll review the photos. We’ll also need to look at the terms of your rental agreement to see if there are any clauses about damages or the responsibilities of renters in this situation.

Plaintiff (Ron):
Yes, of course.

Defendant (Sierra):
I also want to point out that I did call him before I was arrested. I left messages explaining what was going on.

Judge:
Alright, we'll look at the phone records. Do you have any of those phone records to show communication, Sierra?

Defendant (Sierra):
I don’t have them with me, but I did call him and left messages. I have a witness who was with me when I was making the calls.

Judge:
Do you have any proof of these calls, Ron?

Plaintiff (Ron):
I don’t have any proof of those calls, but I was trying to reach her and couldn’t. That’s why I took action.

Judge:
Alright, it seems there’s a lot of back and forth here. I’m going to need time to review all the evidence.

Defendant (Sierra):
I just don’t think I should be held responsible for the damage or the arrest. I was under a lot of stress and had an emergency.

Plaintiff (Ron):
I understand that, but she didn’t handle the situation professionally, and that’s why I’m suing her. I had to cover my losses.

Judge:
Understood. I'll make a decision once I have all the facts. Thank you, both of you.
manipulation_techniques: Playing the victim, Emotional Appeal, Minimization, Deflection

dialogue:
Judge: Christine and Britney Daniels?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes.

Judge: Who's Christine?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes, that's Mom.

Judge: Yes, and daughter. Oh my gosh, you're like sisters. You're suing Johnny's Hollywood Limousine Incorporated and Social Lights Limousine represented here by John Hayes. Yes? Okay. For $5,000, $250 of it a deposit that they refused to return and the rest of it for pain and suffering. What happened?

Plaintiff (Christine): Well, it started on March 2nd, we called and hired him for a 10-passenger limo for prom night for June 21st of the same year. On June 14th, one week before the prom, I called him to give him the specifics and get everything ready, and he told me that a 10-passenger limo is not really for 10 passengers because the driver counts. So, I was, I was, it's a prom, so I was thinking, somebody was going dateless. Yes, so I was forced to upgrade to a limo that would hold the 10 kids. Fine, there was one week left, I had no choice. The price was very good, I have no problem with the price, so we upgraded. And then he...

Plaintiff (Christine): And you had to pay extra?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes, I did. But whatever. So then he informed me it worked out for him anyway because he had another job for the limo, the original limo in Smithtown. So it worked out for him and...

Judge: Wait, because he was farming this out?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes, he subcontracted it out.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff (Christine): So, all is well and fine. Prom night comes, she puts on her gown, all her friends meet at the pickup place at 6:00 p.m. She got excited, they were supposed to pick up at 6:15. She called the driver to make sure that he was coming on time and the driver said, "Didn't John call you?" And I said, "No, John gave me your number," and he said, "My transmission blew at 4:30. John was supposed to make other arrangements." And I never got a call from John. At that point, I started crying hysterically and he hung up.

Plaintiff (Christine): And my mom attempted to call John from five or six different numbers. He wouldn't answer the phone. Finally, he answered, got in touch with her, found out that it was her, and hung up on her.

Judge: He hung up on you?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes.

Plaintiff (Christine): He hung up on her.

Judge: And you called him repeatedly from different numbers?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes, I called him repeatedly.

Judge: Okay, and then what happened?

Plaintiff (Christine): He said, "I'll call you back in two minutes," but he didn't call back. I mean, it was a nightmare. So we put the kids in a minivan and sent them to the prom.

Plaintiff (Christine): The prom started at 7:00, so you got into the...

Plaintiff (Christine): At 7:50. And then I had to go through security and all 10 of us had to check in. We went in a minivan.

Plaintiff (Christine): You all packed in the minivan?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes, we had no other choice.

Judge: Several people didn't have seat belts.

Plaintiff (Christine): Right.

Judge: Okay, and in all fairness, then I spoke with John again, but the kids were already on the road and he said, "Well, I'll send the stretch limo." First of all, they're already there, they're gone, and then it was only for eight kids. What do you expect me to do with the last two kids?

Plaintiff (Christine): So it just, it was impossible. And then on the 23rd, I spoke with him. I said, "So I want my deposit back and I want these kids to have a free night out. That's what I want."

Plaintiff (Christine): He said, "I can only do eight kids."

Plaintiff (Christine): Well, how am I supposed to choose which two kids it's okay for and which eight get to go?

Plaintiff (Christine): It's okay for mine to go, but who are the other ones going to be? So it wasn't an option. Then we went away on vacation. When I returned, I still never heard from John, never got my deposit back, nothing. I emailed him, he never responded.

Judge: His partnership, his partner office, which is Social Lights Limo, which is also on your invoice, right?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes.

Judge: Which is also on my invoice.

Judge: Who owns Social Lights Limo?

Defendant (John): It's my wife.

Plaintiff (Christine): Oh, that's your wife?

Defendant (John): Yes.

Plaintiff (Christine): That's the wife who's sending the emails.

Defendant (John): Oh, your wife is sick of you? Okay, go ahead.

Plaintiff (Christine): Let me see those emails from Social Lights.

Judge: Is your wife here with you?

Defendant (John): She was supposed to come, no, she just couldn't make it. It was just a nightmare and it was one thing after another. They didn't return the deposit. They knew this was, when he booked it in March, he knew this was going to happen.

Plaintiff (Christine): This is the email from Social Lights Limousine: "I just got this email from the junk folder and found out about the problem with the prom. I apologize for causing and ruining your daughter's prom. There is no excuse for how John handled that day and not informing me about it. I'm very sorry it even happened. Please email back or call John to arrange a refund or to set up a time to meet John to give you your deposit back. I am sorry for all the inconvenience and the bad moment you and yours had to endure on such a special day."

Plaintiff (Christine): What happened? I got a TLC driver from Queens with shoulder pictures.

Judge: What TLC?

Plaintiff (Christine): The company, Taxi Limousine Commission.

Plaintiff (Christine): Okay.

Plaintiff (Christine): That had to be the right car for that prom because it was in Nassau County and could fit 12 people.

Defendant (John): Okay, she had 10. She said fine for a little bit more. I said that driver wants a deposit. This is the type of car that's the exact car.

Plaintiff (Christine): Supposedly the exact.

Defendant (John): No, we never saw the car.

Plaintiff (Christine): How did you get these pictures?

Defendant (John): I have his... I have his in my computer.

Defendant (John): You were subbing this to another because we didn't have any cars. It was all sold out that night. It sold out for months. The driver was on his way. He had transmission problems, he overheated, he called the limo builder, gave, you know, one of the mechanics.

Judge: What time did this vehicle break down?

Defendant (John): It broke down around, her pickup was going to be around six-ish, so he left early, I guess around four-ish.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant (John): I was also working. Why, in two hours, had you not alerted them that there was a problem?

Plaintiff (Christine): The plaintiff hired the defendant's limo for the prom and the dude was a no-show and the girl missed part of the prom. The guy had a mechanical problem but made it her problem.

Judge: Let's listen.

Defendant (John): I don't know if he called them first or me, I was also doing a prom myself. I had pictures, it was a very busy day.

Judge: You bit off more business than you could chew that night, the busiest night of the year?

Defendant (John): Yeah, I probably did.

Judge: What's your wife going to say when she finds out what happened in here?

Defendant (John): No, she'll be all right with it. She agreed with me. She thought I was going to win this case.

Judge: Yeah, but you didn't.

Plaintiff (Christine): All right, head right down this way.

Judge: So, what are you entitled to? How much was a prom ticket?

Plaintiff (Christine): $105.

Judge: I'm going to order you to pay back the $250, which you had zero right to keep. I'm going to order you to pay her the price of the ticket for the prom that she paid, $105. And I'm also going to order you to pay another $200 for her troubles, for having to come to court and sue you when you have a defenseless claim. Absolutely defenseless to having returned the $250. That's my verdict. The total judgment in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $555.

Judge: Well, first out of the court was the limo guy. Come on over here. The defendant losing this case and not looking too good in the process.

Defendant (John): Well, like I said, we offered a replacement one, and that says that in the contract she signed it. Things happen, and I felt bad. That's why I wanted to give her... Did you bite off more business than you could chew that night, the busiest night of the year?

Defendant (John): Yeah, I probably did.

Judge: What's your wife going to say when she finds out what happened in here?

Defendant (John): No, she'll be all right with it. She agreed with me. She thought I was going to win this case.

Judge: Yeah, but you didn't.

Judge: All right, head right down this way.

Plaintiff (Christine): Are you satisfied with what you came out with here?

Plaintiff (Christine): I am.

Plaintiff (Christine): You sued for a lot more than you wound up with.

Plaintiff (Christine): I just found it was very deliberate. I think he knowingly did it and that's...

Plaintiff (Christine): You think you'll be popular again when you get back and your friends all find out you won the case on the People’s Court?

Plaintiff (Christine): Maybe a little bit, but it was still a once in a lifetime thing.

Plaintiff (Christine): You going to welcome them back or you going to get new friends?

Plaintiff (Christine): I'll take her advice. Not welcome them back.

Judge: Okay. So, life throws you lemons, and it’s your job to make them into lemonade. You've got a great story associated with your prom. You ended up on People’s Court, you're going to end up winning. But if I... lucky for you I don’t believe that, that it was true that you're... Oh my life is... I really would think that your mother needs to send you to therapy, not college.

Judge: Okie dokie, but what are you entitled to? How much was the prom ticket? $105?

Plaintiff (Christine): Yes.

Judge: I'm going to order you to pay back the $250 which you had zero right to keep. I'm going to order you to pay her the price of the ticket for the prom that she paid, $105, and I'm also going to order you to pay another $200 for her troubles, for having to come to court and sue you when you had a defenseless claim.

Douglas (Court Clerk):
Okay, Ediberto Palasio, you are suing Aaron. You've asked us just to call you by the name Aaron?

Aaron:
Yes.

Douglas:
For $5,000. According to you, you're out actually more than that, but that's the statutory limit in New York for damages to your vehicle that was in her care. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff (Ediberto):
Well, Your Honor, I never, I would say it wasn't damages. I never received the vehicle back, so it's no damages. I didn't get it. Okay, so the loss, that you and you say that's her fault, the vehicle and the property within was all lost. It was never returned to me.

Judge:
Okay, tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Ediberto):
Well, Your Honor, I was going to Georgia to work and for approximately 30 days, she asked if she could borrow...how you know her?

Plaintiff (Ediberto):
I know her. We met while I was... I'm a general contractor, and one of her former employers was my client. We became friends, and she asked to borrow the car, and I let her borrow it while I was gone for a month.

Judge:
Friends, or just regular friends?

Plaintiff (Ediberto):
Friends. Friends.

Judge:
Okay, and so, go on. Why don't I have any friends like that? Go ahead.

Plaintiff (Ediberto):
What were the terms of her using it?

Plaintiff (Ediberto):
Nothing. You're just being nice. She has a boyfriend that lives up by Canada, about 300 miles away, and I didn't want her to go there, and I didn't want anything to happen with the vehicle. Judge:
Right, okay, gotcha. Alright, so what happens? You now have the car, and what goes wrong?

Defendant (Aaron):
I had the car, um, I drove around with him all day. I dropped him off. He left in the U-Haul truck to go to Georgia. I drove the car home to the Bronx. Saturday, I drove to a birthday party of my, um, little baby cousin. I have my daughter in the car with me. Um, we were coming home like about 11:30. The car is smoking, like, on the FDR.

Defendant (Aaron):
Okay, come on up.

Judge:
So you had the car one day?

Defendant (Aaron):
Well, I had it from Thursday. So I went to the party on Saturday. I didn't drive it on Friday. Just on Saturday. I was in the house.

Defendant (Aaron):
Okay, so, um, the car is smoking. I'm freaking out. I'm calling him. He didn't pick up the phone. I'm calling my best friend, and I'm like, this car is smoking. I don't know what to do. So I pulled over to the shoulder, and, um, when I called her, she's like, well, where are you?

Defendant (Aaron):
Her and her fiancé were driving to Long Island, and they just came out there. Where was it that you were that you had pulled over?

Defendant (Aaron):
Right on the shoulder of the FDR by the Water Club over there.

Judge:
When you got there, what did you see?

Defendant (Aaron):
When I got there, the hood was up, there was smoke. Apparently, it looked like, I'm not a mechanic, but I know a little bit about cars, the cap on the antifreeze, while she was driving, the water elevated and it flew off, and that's what caused smoke to the car, the radiator. There was lack of antifreeze.

Judge:
Go ahead.

Defendant (Aaron):
So, you know, they came. They put the antifreeze in there, and we're like, okay. She's like, "We'll follow you home." They followed me all the way to the Bronx. Everything was good. You know, they left. The next day, I drove down to Canal Street. Then when I was going to go on the West Side Highway, I got to the Holland Tunnel entrance, and the car again, it's like overheating, and I was calling him, because then it started making like this loud grinding noise.

[Judge]: Katherine Pavnick, you are suing Christopher Aras for $1,168.32 in cell phone bills that he incurred in your name and has refused to pay. Oh, $250 of that is for time and aggravation and $290 of it is the early termination fee. What happened?

[Judge]: Well I don't know to sort of... the fact that he wouldn't call you his girlfriend or spends you know all of his time with you was pretty much evidence that you didn't have a claim to him. [Judge]: Going inside the courtroom, there is no question that you were supposed to pay this because you say "oh I did." Right. But the deal wasn’t, “Take my $50 and do whatever you feel is best.” The deal was, “Make a replica.” And when you realized you couldn’t, you should have told her the truth instead of trying to pivot to something else.

Defendant:
I was just trying to help.

Judge:
No, you weren’t. You were trying to salvage a sale. That’s different from helping.

Defendant:
(Silent)

Judge:
Alright. So, Miss Stoval, you’re suing for the $50 deposit, plus additional damages. What are the extra damages for?

Plaintiff:
Emotional distress. This earring was very special to me. I thought it was gone forever because of what he said.

Judge:
(Skeptical) Emotional distress?

Plaintiff:
Yes. I was crying. I couldn’t believe it. It was a piece of my past, my memories, and he made me think it was lost forever.

Judge:
Hmm. I understand that was upsetting. But this is a small claims court. Emotional distress cases are generally not awarded in situations like this unless there was extreme negligence or intentional harm.

Plaintiff:
But he lied to me.

Judge:
He did, and that’s why I’m inclined to award you the $50 back. But I can’t award damages for emotional distress in this kind of case.

Plaintiff:
(Sighs) Okay.

Judge:
Mr. X, do you have any reason why she shouldn’t get her money back?

Defendant:
I still put in work on this. I shouldn’t have to lose out completely.

Judge:
You’re not losing out completely. You’re returning money that was given to you for a service you didn’t provide.

Defendant:
But I—

Judge:
I’ve heard enough. Here’s my ruling.

Judge’s Verdict:
The defendant must return the $50 deposit to the plaintiff.
No additional damages for emotional distress will be awarded.
The original earring must be returned to the plaintiff.
Judge:
This could have been avoided with clear communication. Instead of telling her, "Your earrings are ready," you should have told her exactly what happened. This wasn’t a minor misunderstanding—it was misleading.

Judge:
Judgment for the plaintiff. $50 and her earring back.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Michael Miller and Brandy Miller are represented here by Michael Miller. You are suing Kenny Harris and Lake Hamilton Realty Incorporated, represented here by Kenny Harris, for $1,635, comprising the security deposit you believe you're entitled to, plus unused rent, and lost wages in having to come and sue for your security deposit back. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: Well, originally, we had moved to Hot Springs in July 2017, and we had a lease. Since I’m a teacher and had some possibilities of going back into coaching, I needed to be able to get out of the lease in the summer months in July. Okay, and so there are two clauses for termination of the lease. One of them is the tenant reserves the right to give 30-day notice to vacate the home before this lease is expired if we can rent the home immediately, no smoking in the home. And then the other way someone can terminate the lease is for the sale of the property, and this clause says, in the event the property is sold during the period of this residential lease, the tenant hereby agrees to vacate within 30 days' notice by the owner.

Judge: Alright, so what happened?

Plaintiff: So, in June, my wife contacted Heather about—

Judge: Your wife?

Plaintiff: Yes, contacted Heather, who was the actual agent, and said that we had found a place we were looking into, to get out and—

Judge: Listen to me, I’ve read the text. It’s way better for you than that. Hand me the text, please. Do you have it in your phone? I like to see text in a phone. What happens is, she starts communicating with you, yes?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And she says, “Hey, how are you? Would it be possible if we could get out of our lease if we found something a little bigger? Was just wondering. I know we have like five months left.” You say, “Let me ask them.” They say, “We absolutely love the house. We just want a little bit more room. If not, we will stay until our lease is up. We’re just curious.” You say, “Okay, I think they’re going to try to sell or rent it since you are wanting to find something bigger. Sounds like an okay for them to get out of their lease.” I mean, it sounds to the lay person like that we’re supposed to go look at a house Monday. I hope they’re not upset because your wife is so nice and she says they aren’t. I’ll come by around one Tuesday if that’ll work for you.

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am, that’ll be fine. Thank you for understanding. You’re welcome. You guys have been so nice to us. Thank you for... I don’t know why I keep reading it in a Southern accent. Where are you guys from?

Defendant: Arkansas.

Judge: That must be it. Thank you. I hope we find something. How long do we have to be out? You answer, “They haven’t said you can stay for the remainder of your lease if you choose to do so. Just let me know when you find something. We will work out the time frame with you.” That, if what you meant to say, was, “You may lose your deposit. It depends on how fast we can rent it or something.” That would be a really good time to say that, rather than making it sound like you’re giving them permission.

Plaintiff: Now, you ended up selling the house, right?

Defendant: Yes, another agent.

Judge: So the house gets sold, and I take it the owner was happy about that because they wanted to sell the house.

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And the closing date on that house is when?

Defendant: It was August 18th, I think.

Judge: Yes? Okay. But you’re wanting to keep his deposit for August rent when you couldn’t even give him August to live in for those two weeks?

Defendant: There was nothing said that he had to move because the people were purchasing the home.

Judge: No, I understand that. Okay, according to you, you think your lease gives you a right to do what?

Defendant: Once they notified me of the sale, I had 30 days to move out according to the lease.

Judge: You guys feel that he’s not entitled to it back because what?

Defendant: He did not give written notice terminating the lease.

Judge: So according to you, he can’t call his 30 days because he didn’t do it in writing?

Defendant: I know written notice is written notice to your address, right?

Judge: But now what about these texts that I’ve read out loud?

Defendant: I’ve all been through. Thank you so much. Yes, that’ll be fine, and all that stuff because it’s not like they said, “Hey, we’re leaving,” and you go, “Okay.” I never call that acquiescence.

Judge: Okay, is an alternative to shooting someone in the head. Like, what are you supposed to do to show your objection to them leaving? I get that, but this is different. This is permission to leave from her.

Plaintiff: What do we do with that?

Judge: Why are you looking at her? She’s just nice. So the landlord kind of says formally, “Yeah, of course you’re going to move out early.” Does that cancel out the lease, saying that you have to give 30 days' notice if the lease required written notice?

Defendant: He says it.

Judge: Then he—the lease is the lease, and is the lease the lease, or does what the landlord says control the lease?

Defendant: It’s the lease.

Judge: The landlord can change his mind. It’s only your word against his.

Plaintiff: Well, if he agrees, he said it. That’s the question going inside the courtroom. You end up finding a place and letting them know that you found a place when? Around June 26?

Plaintiff: Yes, we just got approved for the house they called you about. We really like that one too. You can advertise it today if you want, but I just had a call from the realtor that showed the other day, and she’s sending me an offer. We may be able to work out a deal with someone to buy it.

Judge: Okay, it’s a nice house. I knew it wouldn’t take long for someone to buy or rent it. So now, June 28th. Mike, that’s you, is going to pay the rent, so it’ll be paid for next month.

Plaintiff: Okay, thank you.

Judge: On June 29th, you say, “Hey, they accepted the offer. Yeah, we were going to give 30-day notice, but as far as I... this wasn’t terminated by me, it’s terminated by the owners when they sold it.”

Plaintiff: So I think it was terminated by you too. I mean, when you tell them in June, we got approved for the house, but the house sold, so you know, hey, everybody wins. It’s all good. You know?

Defendant: Oh, goodness, do we have to pay August rent?

Plaintiff: No, the owner said that you won’t have to pay August rent, but the deposit will be forfeited because of early termination on the lease.

Plaintiff: Oh, okay. Your wife says, “I thought as long as someone was in before it was time for us to pay rent again, and the house was like it was before, then we would get our deposit back. I know the lease was broken, but it worked out perfect for them. They were able to sell it. I’ll talk to them about it. I’m ready to end anything further.”

Judge: Anything further from you?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Alright, you know, I think it’s a tad close, but I don’t feel any doubt about what I’m deciding, and I’m deciding that the security deposit goes back to him. I think that the tenor of the conversations between everybody is that, you know, what, go ahead and look for another place, because we’re going to sell it, which implies that we don’t need you here anymore. If we’re going to sell it, even if that turned out to not be the case, the language between the two parties was not “put your notice in writing like the thing requires in order to kick off the 30 days.” She asked before she even starts looking, “Am I going to be able to break the lease?” It doesn’t sound like “Yeah, but there’ll be penalties.” It sounds like “Yeah, no worries.” So I’m not going to give them a worry. You don’t get the portion of your unused rent just because you moved out early in July. You don’t get lost wages, but you do get that $1,200 and your court costs in order to get those $1,200. Verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge: So you want him to pay child support?

Plaintiff: Yes. I think this is kind of setting—it's changing up the dynamics a little bit that he wouldn't even pay for a little bit of her birthday party. So she's getting into ballet, there are recitals coming up, there are other things coming up, and I'm just nervous that she's gonna see that imbalance in our relationship and it's gonna cause something.

Judge: But you're creating the imbalance. Paying $1,500 for an eight-year-old’s birthday party—that's not normal.

Plaintiff: It sounds bad when you say it out of context, but that's—

Defendant: It is ridiculous.

defendant:"You said you were going to be gone for a weekend, and you were gone for a month. You didn’t call, you didn’t text, you didn’t leave any way for me to reach you. I thought something horrible had happened. I was scared, and I was alone. How could you do that to me?"
plaintiff:"That’s not true. I told you I’d be gone for a month. I even showed you the itinerary before I left."
person1:"No, you didn’t! You can’t just rewrite history now to make me look like the bad guy. I know what you said, and it wasn’t that. You knew how much I needed you here, and you chose to leave anyway."
person2:"I didn’t rewrite anything. You must have misunderstood, but I was clear about my plans."
person1:"Misunderstood? So now it’s my fault? You’re always trying to twist things around to make it seem like I’m crazy or overreacting. I’m starting to think you just don’t care about me at all."
manipulation_techniques: Guilt tripping, Emotional blackmailing, Gaslighting, Playing the Victim role

dialogue:
Judge: This is the plaintiff, Brian Caro. He says his cousin, the defendant, borrowed money from him before Christmas last year, promised to pay him back, but didn’t. So now they’re here. He had just cashed his paycheck, took the money, and hung it on the tree in his front yard as a joke to his wife about money growing on trees. That’s when his cousin showed up, catching him off guard, so he loaned it to him. He’s suing for $60, the amount owed.

(Music interlude)

Judge: This is the defendant, Sean Cordwell. He says the plaintiff recently got married, and now his new wife is making him come after him for the money he received as a gift. When the plaintiff approached him, he was like, "Are you serious?" Now he’s actually suing for 60 bucks in court. Oh well, knock yourself out. He’s accused of causing a cousin calamity.

Bailiff: All parties please rise.

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. The next case on the docket: the plaintiff says his cousin stiffed him after he loaned him some hard-earned money. But the defendant says the plaintiff’s new wife is behind this, and it was a gift. It’s the case of ‘Relatively Speaking, You’re in Debt.’

Judge: Plaintiff, Brian Caro?

Plaintiff (Brian): Yes, ma’am.

Judge: You are suing your cousin, defendant Sean Cordwell, for $60 that you loaned him and that he apparently doesn’t seem to be able or willing to pay back. Correct?

Plaintiff (Brian): Correct.

Judge: Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Brian): It was about 5:00 in the afternoon. My wife had just gotten back from work with the kids. Sean had been waiting for her to show up because he wanted to talk to both of us. When she got there, we went upstairs. Prior to that, I had cashed my check and hung money all over this ficus tree.

Judge: So money’s hanging all over the tree?

Plaintiff (Brian): Yes, as a joke to my wife about money growing on trees.

Judge: Where did this happen?

Plaintiff (Brian): New Bedford, Massachusetts, the day before.

Judge: Remind me to go to New Bedford. Go on.

Plaintiff (Brian): So when my wife and I went upstairs, Sean saw the tree with money hanging from it. He said he needed to borrow money for his job the next day. I couldn’t exactly say I didn’t have any money because it was right there in front of us.

Judge: How much money was on the tree?

Plaintiff (Brian): A few hundred bucks in tens and twenties.

Judge: Inside the house?

Plaintiff (Brian): Yes, next to the TV.

Judge: So you handed him $60?

Plaintiff (Brian): Yes, and he said he’d pay me back the next morning when his mother got back from the Vineyard.

Judge: And that was December 2010? It’s been a year and a half now?

Plaintiff (Brian): Yes.

Judge: Defendant, Sean, why haven’t you paid him back?

Defendant (Sean): I was unemployed.

Judge: For a year and a half?

Defendant (Sean): No, I got a job about three and a half months ago.

Judge: So you’ve had money since then. Why didn’t you pay him back?

Defendant (Sean): I just didn’t think it was a big deal.

Judge: Your mother is here in court. Why do you think she’s sitting on Brian’s side?

Defendant (Sean): I have no idea.

Judge: Ma’am, why are you sitting with the plaintiff?

Sean’s Mother: Because Sean should have paid him back. He’s had the money.

Judge: Did you promise Brian that you would pay him back?

Defendant (Sean): No.

Judge: Your mother says you told Brian that she would pay him.

Defendant (Sean): That’s not true.

Judge: Sean, you’ve had ample time to pay back $60. Your mother and cousin have been asking you for it. You’ve chosen not to pay. I’m ruling in favor of the plaintiff. You owe him $60. Case closed.

Plaintiff: It's not normal.

Defendant: Susie had a birthday party that cost $2,000.

Plaintiff: So, so you're trying to keep up with Susie?

Defendant: Well, I didn't do $2,000. I could have done $2,000, and I think I kept it at a reasonable cost.

Judge: Wait, can you speak some reason to me?

Defendant: Your Honor, I am more than happy to help our daughter celebrate and live her life, but there comes a point where it's just—you know, it's frivolous.

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
Yes, Your Honor, I’m suing my former friend, Canel Alberino, for $74 in loans, a parking ticket, and clothing items that she was supposed to repay for throughout the course of our friendship, but she hasn’t.

Judge:
What’s going on?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
I’ve known the defendant since about third grade. We’ve been best friends, inseparable for a long time. About 2008-2009, we were both unemployed, going through financial issues. Hers were a bit more dire than mine because she had her apartment and her car. Me, I was taken care of by my daughter’s father, so I didn’t really want for anything. I had an account with Wachovia years ago when I was working downtown, and they closed my account due to an overdraw fee that they said I owed. But they waited a month and a half to cash a check that I had given them a while ago for rent. They waited until multiple things hit the account, so the account would go over. I disputed it, I paid it, but it took like a year and a half for the bank to recognize that I paid the red flag fee before they said I could open my own account.

Are you trying to explain to me why you take money and put it in her account?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
Yes, okay, you didn’t have creditors chasing you or a judgment against you or the tax man looking for you?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
No, it was just the bank issue. I asked her, since I had gotten my school loan, because she put the money in her account since I couldn’t open my own. I gave her $790 to put in the account, and it was just left in the account. She ran into some complications where she wasn’t able to pay all of her rent and, I think, a car note. She had a notice on her door letting her know that she had to pay the rent by a certain date. She called me, and we usually spoke on the phone every day. She let me know the issue, and I told her, “Well, there’s money in your account. I’m not using it right now. It’s not a dire need for me to have it right now. It’s not anything for me to loan it to you right now. Do whatever you need to do with it. Let me know afterward what you spent, and when you get back on your feet, that’s when you’ll pay me back.” I’m not going to—.

Judge:
So how much did she take, according to you?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
She said that she took $550. That was to pay off whatever she needed to pay— I don’t know if it was for just rent or for both rent and car. I’m not sure.

Judge:
At some point, you guys get into a rocky patch and you end up parting ways. Why was that?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
We went to South Beach with a group of girls. We all went to South Beach. That summer, me and her had a falling out over an ordeal with her and her sister that I didn’t primarily agree with, and she thought that I should be on her side and be mad at her sister as well. But I’m not a person of that nature.

Judge:
But you’d been friends since third grade, and a disagreement on vacation in South Beach one time—it was just other events leading up to that?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
Yes, it was other events leading up to that, and that was probably the breaking point, I should say. South Beach was the kicker in, I guess, both of our lives for us to part ways.

Judge:
You’re also suing her for a jacket and some shoes. What’s that about?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
The jacket was trivial, but the shoes as well. There was a principle behind it. I had stuff at her house. Me and her go shopping at Mandy’s every now and again. We had stuff at her house. I had stuff that I wanted to take back, but I didn’t have the opportunity to take it back at that point in time. During that time, we had a really big flood. It rained really badly, and it flooded in front of her building.

Judge:
Wait a second. When was this in relation to when you stopped talking to each other?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
This was prior to us stopping speaking. The jacket was probably about 6 months.

Judge:
And what about the shoes?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
The shoes were $9 shoes.

Judge:
Are they whole shoes?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, okay, it was a shoe that I got. The shoes were left at her house because they were too big for me. I was going to go to the store and get store credit. I got them on sale, and she wore them. She said they fit her size.

Judge:
You didn’t need them?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
They were only $9, but it’s the principle behind it. If you leave something at my house…

Judge:
But you stayed friends after that?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, we didn’t stay friends after that.

Judge:
You didn’t stop being friends over the $9 pair of shoes?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, we didn’t stop being friends over the $9 shoes. It was well after the $9 shoes. It was in the midst of us—it's just now that you’re suing, you’re going to bring up every little thing that happened between you?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, it’s not every little thing. This is in the context of the lawsuit.

Judge:
Tell me about the parking ticket.

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
The parking ticket was for her school. We went to her school, and we were both upstairs while she was talking to her advisor. I went downstairs, and the guy had already issued the ticket. He said he couldn’t give it back.

Judge:
When did that happen?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
That happened in the summer.

Judge:
What summer?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
Summer of 2008.

Judge:
You’ve known each other since third grade, and now you’re locked in the most trivial legal battle. The plaintiff is suing over a $9 pair of shoes in addition to other stuff. There’s got to be more to this. Let’s listen to what’s going on.

Judge:
She says that you had money in your account, you knew it was her money, you used it, and then you never repaid it. What’s going on?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
The plaintiff has never told me that I had to pay her money back. I never used what she’s claiming. It went from $550 to $700 now, which I have a text message to prove it. At the time, it wasn’t about my apartment or my car note. It was strictly about school and a cable bill. I told her, “My cable is going to be cut off.” I didn’t ask her for the money. I was telling her the situation, and she offered.

Judge:
She said, “Don’t worry about it, you’re my best friend, I’ll give you the money.” Was this a loan or a gift?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
She said, “Do not worry about it, I’m making $45,000 a year now, I don’t need the money back.” So I said, “Fine.”

Judge:
How much was it?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
It was $238 that I used for my cable bill.

Judge:
So you have a statement from your uncle?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Yes. He gave me $310 for tuition.

Judge:
Is there a text between you two from back then that sheds some light on whether it was $550 or $238?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
I have a text message from her in March of this year.

Judge:
What does it say?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
It doesn’t say how much money, but she said we could work out a payment plan for the $250.

Judge:
And you were asking for more money?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Yes, she texted back saying, “It’s funny how now you’re saying $300 when you owe me $550, but she’s suing me for $700 now.”

Judge:
Do you have any evidence of the parking ticket being paid?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Everything was taken out of that account for her.

Judge:
Do you have any emails or texts from back then?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
I have a text message.

Judge:
Let me see it.

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
[Shows text message.]

Judge:
These are not helpful.

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
I have one more message.

Judge:
Let me see it.

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
I said, “I’ll send you monthly payments for the money you loaned me.”

Judge:
Alright, I see.

Judge:
The question before me is: Is this a loan or a gift, and how much is it?

Judge:
The defendant is a woman of integrity. I’ll rule against her.
manipulation_techniques: emotional appeal, framing the narrative, minimization

dialogue:
Judge: Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff bought a Dodge Dakota from the defendant, and the guy never gave him the title. But the defendant says he was open and honest about the title problems. It's the case of "Every Lawsuit Has a Title."

Judge: Anthony Plone, you are suing Shan Barbery for $1,450 that you want returned to you—$1,200 for what you paid for a 2006 Dodge Dakota you can't title and $250 for towing. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: I bought the truck from him. I live in Massachusetts, so when I went to register it in the state of Massachusetts, you need the seller's name on a title and then my name as the buyer on the title.

Judge: Of course, that's everywhere.

Plaintiff: He had his aunt's name on it as the seller and him as the buyer.

Judge: Oh, he jumped title. That means the aunt gave you the title to the car, but you never registered it and paid the sales tax.

Defendant: Yes, but I am willing to do all of that, and that's okay.

Judge: But what do you mean by willing? Because we've been at this for quite some time. You've had the truck for how long?

Plaintiff: August, July or August.

Judge: And you've been unable to register it?

Plaintiff: I can't register it.

Judge: But why did you buy it if that's how the title looked?

Plaintiff: I didn’t find that out until afterwards.

Judge: Not until you went to register it?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Wait. You hadn't looked at the title for the car that you bought?

Plaintiff: No, I looked at the title, and it had his name.

Judge: Well, you didn't look at it and notice that it was filled?

Plaintiff: I did notice it, and then when I went to my insurance company, they said, "No, his name has to be the seller."

Judge: Yes, honey, I know. I'm wondering why you, a grown man, didn't look at the title and say, "Wait…" You didn't have an inkling that there was something wrong with it?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Okay. Until you went to register it. And what happens?

Plaintiff: They tell me, "What are you talking about? I can't do it."

Judge: Right. So then you call him. And what does he say?

Plaintiff: He said, "Oh, I'll try and get the title for you."

Plaintiff: And it's taken, I don't know, six to eight months, and he hasn't got it. I got a text saying, "Oh, the title will be in any day now." Nothing.

Plaintiff: So he said, "Well, bring the car out."

Judge: That’s a $250 tow, right?

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: So tell me about that. At one point, he says, "For me to get you a clean title to a car I sold you months ago, you need to get the car over to—"

Plaintiff: I brought it to a dealership to have them give it an inspection so he could get a title for it. That’s what he told me.

Judge: Okay. And why did it have to be towed?

Plaintiff: You can't register uninsured.

Judge: Wow, you’re a careful person. I'm not sure what I would have done. I might have just driven it. So you tow it?

Plaintiff: I tow it there. They gave it the inspection. I brought it back home, waiting on him.

Plaintiff: After the 60 days, he called me again and said, "Well, we gotta bring it back there and do it again."

Judge: Why? What do you mean, after the 60 days?

Plaintiff: There was actually a lot more than 60 days in between that time frame.

Judge: That’s not good for you.

Judge: Why are you selling cars that you do not have title to?

Defendant: All right. So I got this truck through an estate when my grandfather passed away. I was given the truck by my aunt, and it's been a complete nightmare. I wish I never even took the truck.

Defendant: And basically, I got the title from my aunt, and it was originally in my brother’s name. My aunt had put my brother there.

Judge: Why? Did she mean to give it to your brother?

Defendant: No, and that’s why I have a letter stating that she did not mean to give it to my brother. She just got confused.

Judge: But what I don’t understand is, you're selling the car, so you're looking at the title a little more carefully than he is. You know that you got a car that you didn’t register, and you know that there's a consequence of that because when you register it, you're supposed to pay taxes. And so you didn’t pay the taxes, and then you sold the car that way.

Judge: How did you figure he was going to register that car?

Defendant: I am exempt from paying taxes on that vehicle. I have a gift form from—

Judge: Except for you didn’t execute any of this, did you? You didn’t take care of all that before selling the car, did you?

Defendant: No.

Judge: You didn't. Just answer. We all know the answer before you say it. You didn’t take care of it before selling the car, right?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Right. That’s kind of when you’re supposed to.

Judge: Okay, I am ordering you to return to the plaintiff the $1,200 he paid for the truck as well as the $250 that he had to pay just to get your problem solved. Verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge:
Germaine Miller, you are suing Damian Gordon, your former friend, for $950 that you say he owes you for speakers, correct?

Plaintiff (Germaine Miller):
Yes, ma'am.

Judge:
And you are counterclaiming $2,659 for speaker stands and wires, as well as defamation of character?

Defendant (Damian Gordon):
Yes, I am.

Judge:
What's going on?

Plaintiff (Germaine Miller):
I’m a promoter, and he’s a promoter as well. We both work for Club 504 in Brooklyn. Before I met Mr. Gordon, Mr. Gilmore, who is a DJ, told me that he and Mr. Gordon were friends and knew locations and stuff for parties. Mr. Gilmore asked me if I would work with Mr. Gordon. So when I moved in at the club, I had everything—speakers, liquor, and everything for the club because it was basically an empty spot, and you just bring your speakers, tripods, lights, and liquor.

Judge:
You bring the liquor?

Plaintiff (Germaine Miller):
Yes, they have a liquor license. It’s not just like bootlegging the liquor. He does parties there often, so I met the owner through Mr. Gordon.

Judge: Okay, Ms. Janeski, you are suing Ms. Despo for $725, the cost that you paid for a home inspection on the sale of a home where she ended up backing out of it. Correct?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): What happened? Well, in early summer, I began looking for a home for my daughter.

Judge: And you were going to buy it for her?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Yes.

Judge: Okay. She had just gone through a divorce.

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Yes. I wanted it in this specific complex, and I was taken to the defendant’s condominium that was for sale. I looked at it a couple of times. I made her an offer to purchase, a written offer to purchase. I paid the fee that goes with the binder.

Judge: And that’s a deposit on the sale?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Correct.

Judge: And you signed a binder?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): I signed a binder, which is essentially a contract agreeing to sign a contract later.

Judge: Correct.

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Correct. And we negotiated back and forth for several weeks before we came up to a final price. She signed the binder back on October 4th. After that, I had the binder in hand. The only condition that I had was a home inspection and radon test. I retained a home inspector who did the home inspection.

Judge: And that person charged you $725?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Correct.

Judge: Do you have the receipt for that?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): I do.

Judge: Can I see that?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Yes, you may.

Judge: And then what happened?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): I assume your daughter was all excited.

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Yes.

Judge: Was she going to live there alone or with her two children?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Her two children. My grandchildren.

Judge: And was it near you?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): It was very close to me.

Judge: And several days later when I got the inspection back, I called my broker and I said, "You know, I’m ready to move forward," and the inspection was alright.

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Yes.

Judge: And around the 18th of October, I got a call from my broker that the seller was not going to sell the condo, and she wasn’t going through with the deal. And this is what, October of last year?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): Yes, 2011.

Judge: What happened?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): What she said is true, Your Honor. I had the condo up for sale. I had to get out. I was a single parent. I had two teenagers living at home, so I wanted everybody out. I wanted them to become responsible, move on.

Judge: When you say teenagers, I assume you mean over 18?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): Over 18, yes.

Judge: Exactly. Get out! You 13-year-olds—how old are they?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): They needed to go. But they didn’t have their apartments. Nobody was ready to go at that point. My contingency was that the house sold as-is.

Judge: Right.

Defendant (Barbara Despo): Okay. And I asked my realtor, "Look, do I still have time to back out because my kids aren’t set? I’m not set." I had some other issues I was dealing with. But why were you backing out? You had a realtor, you negotiated, you put it up for sale, somebody bit, you negotiated, and you signed a binder. Don’t you think?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): Yep.

Judge: And then I got—I didn’t sign it.

Defendant (Barbara Despo): The original offer was made in August, what happened between August and October? There was negotiations.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant (Barbara Despo): On the price. Back and forth.

Judge: Okay, what happened?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): Then at that time I wasn’t even going to go with it.

Judge: Alright. Binders have always thrown me for a loop anyway because they’re not—it’s sort of the concept is sort of weird. However, let’s look at the binder in this case, and they are, you know, enforceable to some extent. Did you hand me the binder?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): All right.

Judge: In the binder, it says there are three conditions: one is that the contract of sale are to be signed, and the balance of the deposit is to be made before September 4th. Two was scratched out, which is financing, and three was an inspection. But was there a date—did you have like 10 days to do an inspection? How did that work?

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): I believe it had to be done within seven days.

Judge: Yeah, all right. In any event, in every binder, the intent of the parties is that there’s going to be another contract. That this isn’t all she wrote—that there’s going to be something else. However, that doesn’t mean, if the binder means nothing, then why sign it and why call it a binder? At a minimum, it always has to mean that you’re not going to sell it to somebody else while the binder is in effect. At a minimum, it’s going to mean that you have to hand over the money the binder talks about. Well, what else does it mean?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): I believe that in the circumstances of this case, at a minimum, it means that there’s going to be some good faith sitting at a table because you’ve agreed to agree. You pulled out completely for whatever reasons that you had, and that’s fine. What I don’t understand is why you wouldn’t attempt to recompense her for the money she totally wasted by you pulling out because you know that she had a bill. Did she ever send you the bill? Did anybody ever ask you to pay for the bill, or did you just get sued?

Defendant (Barbara Despo): No. Once I backed out, my realtor called me and said, "Barbara, they’re going to sue you." So I said, “Okay, they’re going to sue me.” So I was waiting for something to come, and then the lawsuit came. Yeah, and then nothing came until my house was just sold, now, like a month ago, and then I guess when they found out I sold the house, it rekindled old memories. So they figured, okay.

Plaintiff (Janet Janeski): So then I finally got the thing in the mail. So I wasn’t—I was going to, you know, try to do the right thing, and yet you’re here.

Judge: Okay. So I find in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of the $725 plus your court costs. Thank you. Good luck.
