So I get back into the car—I left my phone in the car, my wife and I—and I got two phone calls from him that I missed.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
So my wife texted him back.

Judge:
Right.

Plaintiff:
And nothing. Two times.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
So then I texted him back. I says, "Why are you ignoring me?" I said to him, "I just want to know how you made out with my toolbox. You know what I mean? Like, did it get there in one piece or what?"

Judge:
Right.

Plaintiff:
So he says, "It got there." That’s what he said. And that was it.

Judge:
Did he say anything went wrong?

Plaintiff:
No.

Judge:
Okay. But then you go on Monday morning—

Plaintiff:
Exactly.

Judge:
—to work, and what do you find?

Plaintiff:
As soon as I got at work, okay, some guy comes up to me, and he was like right there. This guy Steve. And he goes, "Dude, the guy that dropped your tools off, the whole box fell off the truck."

Judge:
Right.

Plaintiff:
And I'm like, "Whoa."

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
So then I walked to my toolbox and everything, and I’m seeing it’s like twisted and bent and whatever. I’m saying like, "Wow." You can see the pictures.

Judge:
And he’s mad at me now?

Plaintiff:
He’s mad at me.

Judge:
The football player?

Defendant:
It’s 2,000 pounds—

Judge:
Hold on, sir. Nobody asked you a question. Is that the football player?

Plaintiff:
Yeah.

Judge:
Okay, go ahead.

Plaintiff:
That’s—that’s the joy of my life.

Judge:
Right.

Plaintiff:
Say—repeat that last part.

Judge:
He’s the joy of your life?

Plaintiff:
No. Oh, I’m sorry, I didn’t mean that.

Judge:
Okay, so the guy did not see the damage occur. Is he out of luck?

Defendant:
He is.

Judge:
Why?

Defendant:
I just think it’s unfortunate that he was in that circumstance and the dude didn’t trust him.

Judge:
Well, so how do you protect yourself?

Defendant:
I would take pictures with my phone before—

Judge:
Yeah. That is the point. Going inside the courtroom.

Judge:
You said that one of the other employees said—

Plaintiff:
He told me that the box fell over on its side. He had to help him pick the box back up.

Judge:
Did that happen?

Defendant:
It’s not a new unit.

Judge:
Right.

Defendant:
This unit was passed on to you by who?

Plaintiff:
No, no. I bought it brand new. My grandfather bought it for me when I first started in the business.

Judge:
So that was how old?

Plaintiff:
Yeah.

Judge:
Yeah?

Plaintiff:
Thirty years ago?

Judge:
Twenty-five years ago?

Plaintiff:
Okay.

Judge:
So this thing is now—the drawer won’t close.

Plaintiff:
So here I am at work on Monday, and I’m trying to—I have to take everything out of the box because all the tools are upside down. They’re all laying in the bottom of the lower box.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
So I’m trying to open up the bottom box—

Judge:
This is fresh damage right here.

Plaintiff:
So I’m trying to open up the bottom drawers on a toolbox.

Judge:
Yeah.

Plaintiff:
I had to drill out the—

Judge:
This is fresh damage.

Defendant:
Whether it’s fresh or not, I didn’t do it. He’s just claiming I did it.

Judge:
Yeah, he is.

Defendant:
He’s claiming I did it.

Judge:
But apparently, he’s not the only one claiming you did it.

Defendant:
Yeah.

Judge:
According to you, nothing happened. It didn’t fall over. Nothing happened.

Defendant:
The only thing that fell was the top box because it’s not connected. That’s what I told the officer when he called me with the police report. Only the top box fell.

Judge:
Show me the police report.

Defendant:
It’s not connected.

Judge:
Did they make you come to the place, or no, they just talked to you on the phone?

Defendant:
They just talked to me on the phone.

Judge:
Show me the police report.

Judge:
So the police called you, and you told them that only the top box fell?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
But you never told the plaintiff that, correct?

Defendant:
No.

Judge:
Why not?

Defendant:
Because he was already texting me like crazy, and I figured he’d just blame me anyway.

Judge:
Well, don’t you think he had the right to know?

Defendant:
I mean, I guess, but the box was old.

Judge:
That’s not the issue here. The issue is whether or not the damage occurred because of how you transported it.

Plaintiff:
Exactly.

Judge:
Do you have any pictures of the toolbox before transport?

Plaintiff:
Yes, I do.

Judge:
Let me see them.

(Plaintiff hands over photos.)

Judge:
Okay. This shows a toolbox in good condition. Do you have any pictures of how it looked when it arrived?

Plaintiff:
Yes, I do.

(Plaintiff hands over another set of photos.)

Judge:
Oh wow. This is significantly bent.

Defendant:
That could have been like that before.

Judge:
No, because I see pictures of it before transport. It was fine. Then after transport, it’s completely bent, drawers don’t close, and it’s clearly damaged.

Defendant:
Well, I didn’t mean for that to happen.

Judge:
That’s not how liability works. If you’re responsible for transporting something, you are responsible for making sure it gets there safely.

(Judge looks over police report.)

Judge:
The police report confirms that the top part of the box fell during transport, but based on the testimony of the plaintiff’s coworker, it looks like the entire unit fell.

(Judge looks at damage estimate.)

Judge:
You’re suing for how much?

Plaintiff:
$2,500 for a replacement toolbox.

Judge:
And how old was this toolbox?

Plaintiff:
About 25 to 30 years old, but in good condition.

Judge:
You can’t get the value of a brand-new toolbox for an older one. However, you are entitled to the fair market value of a similar used one in good condition.

(Judge checks estimated value.)

Judge:
I’m going to award the plaintiff $1,500. That is a reasonable replacement cost based on similar used toolboxes in good condition.

Defendant:
That’s not fair.

Judge:
It is fair. You were responsible for the transport, you improperly secured the load, and as a result, it was damaged. Judgment in favor of the plaintiff for $1,500.

Bailiff:
Court is adjourned.

**Judge:** This is the plaintiff, Kathy Mourich. She says she arrived home one day to find a huge hole in the cement in front of her house. An eyewitness told her a big bus drove up over the curb and then parked on the cement, which caused the damage. She has concrete proof. The defendant said she would come out and investigate the damage but never did, and here they are. She's suing for the $540 she's owed to fix her damaged cement.

This is the defendant, Karen Holzwarth, owner of K&H Bus Service. She says she did indeed investigate the plaintiff's bogus claim, and there's no way one of her buses did the damage because it's on a spot where none of her buses could even get to. This woman is trying to place the blame on one of her drivers when he did nothing wrong, and there's no way she's going to pay for damage that wasn't caused by her bus. She's accused of causing a crater.

All parties, please rise.

Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff says the defendant’s bus drove over a curb and left a huge hole in the cement, but the defendant says no way did her bus do the damage. It's the case of Bus-Ted. Litigants have been sworn in, Your Honor.

**Judge:** Thank you, Douglas. Kathy Mourich, you are suing Karen Holzwarth and K&H Bus Service. You're the owner?

**Defendant:** Yes, ma’am.

**Judge:** Okay, for $540, the cost of pavement repair, because according to you, one of her drivers was negligent. Tell me what happened.

**Plaintiff:** Okay. Um, on November 10th of last year, when I was coming home from work, I said, "Oh my God, my neighbor’s really going to be ticked. Somebody broke his pavement!" And here it was mine. And I was ticked. And I went—I went into the corner store to find out if they knew what had happened because they had cameras, right? And the—the gentleman that was the proprietor at the time said, "Yes, the school bus pulled on your pavement."

**Judge:** Oh, so he had actually seen it?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** Is he here today?

**Plaintiff:** No.

**Judge:** All right. But you have the pictures from his surveillance footage?

**Plaintiff:** Okay, let's see the pictures.

**Judge:** So you find out who the company is from these pictures?

**Plaintiff:** Well, from the actual video. My niece and her daughter and I went in to view the cameras, and you could see—you could see K&H School Bus Service or whatever it was on the side.

**Judge:** Yes, you can. Oh, you're not going to be happy. Did you speak to the driver?

**Plaintiff:** I did, Your Honor.

**Judge:** And what did your driver say?

**Plaintiff:** He said, "I parked on the curb." He says, "I didn’t go no further than the curb."

**Judge:** So is it possible, or do you believe that the bus parked on the curb but didn’t jump the curb?

**Plaintiff:** No, absolutely not. I think it had to have jumped the curb.

**Judge:** What do you say?

**Defendant:** I don’t think there’s any way that he could have just parked on the curb after, like, not doing it on purpose, basically.

**Judge:** Right, right, right. Going inside the courtroom—what does "curb" mean?

**Plaintiff:** Oh, well, in Philadelphia, when we have our houses, the pavements are actually what they call cement slabs.

**Judge:** Yeah, okay.

**Plaintiff:** And the curb would be just a long piece of curbing, which would not be cement. It would be other than cement.

**Judge:** Okay, so is it part of the street?

**Plaintiff:** Yeah, it divides the street from the actual sidewalk.

**Judge:** And what is the curb made of?

**Plaintiff:** Could be slate. I think most of them are slate. I don’t believe it's cement.

**Judge:** Would you like to see what the bus driver did?

**Defendant:** Yes, I would love to.

**Judge:** Okay. Why didn’t you just send her this picture?

**Plaintiff:** Well, I did speak with Ms.—

**Judge:** No, no. This is different from sending the picture. A picture is worth a— I can’t wait to see the look on her face when I show her the picture. Why would you not have sent her the picture? When did you get the picture?

**Plaintiff:** I—I don’t remember when I actually took—

**Judge:** When did you get it? You helping her?

**Plaintiff’s Niece:** Um, I was with her at the corner store, but it was a few days after when they were able to get the pictures off of the video surveillance.

**Judge:** Okay, so a few days after. Did anybody send the pictures to her?

**Plaintiff:** No.

**Judge:** That would have saved everything.

**Plaintiff:** Oh, yeah.

**Judge:** Well, I’m going to see—we’re going to see if that would have saved everything. Take that picture to that nice lady right there. Pretty bad, right?

**Defendant:** Actually, what she was com—what she said was up here was broken—

**Judge:** Where it's caved in?

**Defendant:** Except that’s not accurate. I’m going to show—come on over here, sweetheart, and give this to her.

**Judge:** I’m sorry—no, I was calling you sweetheart. I’m sorry. You’re not used to me calling you sweetheart? Bring—I can’t stand it. I cannot stand it. I—I—I just—I can’t. Come take a look at that.

**Defendant:** Right. No, that’s pretty bad.

**Judge:** He didn’t do that?

**Defendant:** I’m sorry, he didn’t do that. I got a picture of him doing it.

**Judge:** No, he said he was parked right here on—

**Defendant:** No, he didn’t say that.

**Judge:** You mean—okay. Is that what you—well, maybe not. What are you saying?

**Defendant:** I’m—I don’t want to put words—what he said was he parked on the curb. I know he said to you something different.

**Judge:** Now we are showing you—I’m seeing that. That’s crazy, right? And also, I’m showing you what he did, because that’s the result of parking that enormous bus on that lady’s sidewalk. You see that, right?

**Defendant:** Yes.

**Judge:** That looks bad, right?

**Defendant:** Yes.

**Judge:** My verdict in this case is for the plaintiff for the amount of the repair and, of course, her court cost. Good luck.

Judge: Nicole Reason and Kirby Gaston, you are suing Natalie Jean, your landlord, for forty-five hundred dollars that you want returned to you—the two months' rent you paid, the security deposit, and the dog deposit—because, according to you, she didn't have a right to lease to you to begin with. What happened?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): Well, um, one day my husband called me and told me he found this apartment on this website that's called classyapartment.com. On the website, it said "apartment for rent for thirteen hundred, call ASAP." My husband called her, he went to see the apartment. The following day I went with him. I seen the apartment. I said, "You know what? I like the apartment." Basically, we're going to go ahead with it. January 1st, we gave a total deposit of 4400, and the third, we gave her an additional hundred dollars, so that made it a whole total of 4,500.

Judge: Okay. Did you sign a lease?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): Yes.

Judge: May I see the lease you signed?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): This is for chicken.

Judge: Do you have the actual lease?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): This is everything that she gave.

Judge: Okay. So she actually gave you a picture?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): No, no, no. Okay, that's a picture of something. Do you have the something?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): I just brought the copies.

Judge: Yeah, never do that. Always bring an original, which is much easier to read than a picture. All right. So it says move in—blah, blah, blah—this will be a month-to-month. So it was month-to-month. All right. Now, what's this other document you gave me a picture of?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): That is a document that she forged the landlord’s name on.

Judge: That you never met the landlord?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): No, I never met the landlord.

Judge: Who is Antoine Sanders?

Plaintiff (Nicole Reason): The landlord. He's right here.

Judge: Okay. Can you switch with him, please?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Yes.

Judge: All right. According to you, do you have a lease with the landlord?

Defendant (Natalie Jean): Yes.

Judge: May I see your lease? You are the landlord? You're the owner of the property?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Yes, I am.

Judge: All right. So now, how long have you been renting to her?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): I never gave her a lease.

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): I've never rented to her. The place—I don't know what you're talking—I never rented an apartment in my house.

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Her friend used to live there. Her friend moved out, and she moved in.

Judge: Okay, so she moved in without your authority?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Yes.

Judge: Okay. Show me the lease. Does it have your name on it or somebody else's?

Defendant (Natalie Jean): My name.

Judge: Take a look at that. Is that your signature and her signature? Because it looks like a lease.

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): This is not my signature.

Judge: That's not your signature?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Definitely not.

Judge: Do you have any ID on you right now?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Yes.

Judge: Pull out any ID that has your signature, please.

Judge: Did you forge it?

Defendant (Natalie Jean): No.

Judge: You've been to court with her already, right?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Yes.

Judge: Why did you go to court?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Because she didn't want to leave when I told her to.

Judge: Why were you trying to get her out?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): Because she's not supposed to be there.

Judge: Yeah, but I mean, don't you want some—was she paying rent?

Plaintiff (Antoine Sanders): No, she wasn't.

Judge: Oh, well, that's a good reason. When was the last time she paid rent?

(Exchange continues as judge questions Natalie Jean about missing rent payments, fraud accusations, and inconsistencies in her statements. Eventually, the judge rules in favor of the plaintiffs.)

Judge: Forty-five hundred dollars, verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket—the plaintiff helped the defendant find two kittens, and the defendant won’t pay the adoption fee. But the defendant says there was never an adoption fee agreement. It’s the case of Kitty Galore.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas.

Bailiff: You're welcome.

Judge: Okay, Mary Chirichella, you are suing Here Kitty Kitty Incorporated, represented here by Leslie Diamond. You're the president?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay. For $180, the amount that you say they owe you as an adoption fee for two kittens, right? That they received and kept rather than giving to you the adoption fee. All right, so tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: Okay. In July of 20__, I rescued two tortoiseshell kittens.

Judge: Where did you rescue them from?

Plaintiff: From a street in a busy area.

Judge: Okay, and were they kittens at the time?

Plaintiff: Yes, they were about 10 to 12 weeks old. It was a location where I’d been doing cat rescue for 12 years, so I had been feeding in that area. I first saw one kitten, and then saw the other one a few days later. A friend of mine, Eileen, agreed to foster them. I provided the food and litter to Eileen, and she took care of them daily. Then I created a flyer for Natasha and Nadia. My phone number was on there, and Eileen and I posted the flyer at various locations. It was a slow summer, the economic crisis was in full swing, and I wasn’t getting the kind of calls I was happy with for them.

Judge: What kind of donation were you looking for?

Plaintiff: Well, originally, just to cover my expenses.

Judge: So what was it for the two of them?

Plaintiff: At the time, I would have even taken $75 for both. At that time, they only had one vet visit, which was $131.

Judge: So you wanted $75 for both of them?

Plaintiff: Yes. It was very slow going. When Eileen had gone to the vet, someone there suggested that she could take the kittens to Petco on Route 3 and show them on weekends with the group run by Ms. Diamond.

Judge: Do you work for Petco?

Defendant: No, we show our cats and kittens at Petco. I've been doing rescue for 20 years, and Here Kitty Kitty is going to celebrate its 9th anniversary in September.

Judge: All right. So what happens next?

Plaintiff: Eileen brings the kittens over and leaves them with her. A woman completes an application, and I spoke to the woman who wanted to adopt them. Then I spoke with Leslie. I asked her how much she was going to charge for the adoption fee. She said $180. I told her I would need that fee to compensate me for what I had already spent. She asked how much I had spent. I said a few hundred dollars. She said she couldn’t give me that. I told her I didn’t expect that much, but I would need the adoption fee.

Defendant: Nobody talked about the adoption fee before all this happened. Ms. Chirichella knew what our adoption fee was. The people who adopted the cats were in their 60s, so we have a program sponsored through Purina that pays the adoption fee for two cats. Then Mary came on the scene and said she wanted the adoption fee after the adoption had already taken place. In all my years of doing this, I sometimes split the fee with someone or write a tax letter.

Judge: So what happens? The cats get adopted, and then what?

Plaintiff: Leslie agreed that she would mail me the adoption fee, but I would have to wait because it was coming from Purina. I said that was fine, I could wait. A few months went by, I suspected something was up, and I called her. She did not return my phone calls. One night, I spoke to her husband, and he said she would get back to me. So I went to see her.

Judge: Why were you avoiding her?

Defendant: I took all her calls. The one night she called, I was very sick, and my husband picked up the phone while I was sleeping.

Judge: According to you, how many messages did you leave?

Plaintiff: Several, at least three.

Judge: So you ended up having to go in person to Petco?

Plaintiff: Yes. As soon as I walked in, Leslie said, "I don’t have your money." I asked why. She said she had some veterinary emergencies and had to use it. I asked when she thought she’d have it, and she said she didn’t know. There was no attempt to work something out or make any payments. She told me, "If you want your money that badly, take me to court." So I said, "Okay, I will."

Judge: You did get paid by Purina?

Defendant: Yes, I did.

Judge: At some point, were you telling her you were going to send her the adoption fee?

Defendant: I never actually stated that I would send her the money, and I never signed anything. I said I would try and see what I could do. We survive by adoption fees. That’s it. We don’t get grants like city or state shelters.

Judge: That’s how you operate, and that’s how she operates too. I have to decide if there was a contract between you two. You didn’t set a price, so I have to set a price. I’m going to split it. I’m ordering you to pay her $90. I strongly suggest that if you’re in this situation, specify the money part in advance. Good luck, folks.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says her cousin invited her into a book club, and they were having an event in Florida. The plaintiff says she got kicked out of the club, and now the defendant refuses to return her money. But the defendant says the plaintiff didn’t follow the rules. It’s the case of I Hate You Like the Dickens. Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: Okay, Shade Martin, you are suing your cousin, Karifa Jones, for $240 that you say she owes you to return for a trip that she wouldn’t let you go on. You say she canceled, and that’s her problem—that she lost the money. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: Okay, so about a year and a half ago, Karifa started a book club. She invited me to join. You know, we meet once a month or so. Around December, the group decided we were going to take our first annual book club trip. It was to go to Florida. So I gave her the money around the last or second week of March for a trip that was going to be in April.

Judge: Okay, April 15th.

Plaintiff: Yes, April 15th. Everything was fine after I gave her the money. There were no problems.

Judge: Were you two getting along?

Plaintiff: We were getting along perfectly fine.

Judge: Was everybody here in the book club?

Plaintiff: No, no, no. And yes.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Plaintiff: The last meeting, I didn’t attend because I wasn’t feeling well. I sent her a text message letting her know. But still, after that, I saw her at my cousin’s dinner—that was April 7th. He had a dinner for his birthday. Me and her spoke, along with her witness. Everything was fine. No problems. The day before the trip, which was April 14th, one of my cousins, Tanisha Williams, called me. She gave me a phone call saying that she would give me my money if she could take my place. I thought she was joking.

Judge: Who is she, and how is she related to her?

Plaintiff: That’s her sister.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So, I’m thinking she’s joking. I’m like, "Okay, yeah, yeah, whatever."

Judge: Why did you say "yeah"? Why didn’t you say, "No, I’m going"?

Plaintiff: I started laughing. I told her that, you know, I’m going on the trip. We both laughed it off. I didn’t think that she was serious. Apparently, they were discussing it at my aunt’s salon. My cousin and my aunts were there as well. Not even a minute later, Karifa calls me, saying, "Oh, how are you going to let someone else take your spot without consulting me?" And I’m like, "Well, I didn’t give her permission to take my spot. I didn’t receive any money. I thought we were joking."

Judge: Then what happens?

Plaintiff: She calls me and says, "How are you going to give someone permission to take your spot without consulting me?" I stated, "Well, I wasn’t serious. We laughed it off. I thought she was joking." She says, "Well, you’ve been acting funny. You don’t call nobody, so I’m just going to bring you your money back, and that’ll be it. You’re not going to be a part of the book club, and you won’t be attending the trip."

Judge: She tells you this verbally?

Plaintiff: Yes, she does. And as we were talking, I pressed the record button on my phone, so it recorded the call and sent it as a text message.

Judge: Okay, then what?

Plaintiff: After that, I said, "Okay, fine. No problem." I wasn’t going to argue. She said she was bringing my money. I said, "Fine." That was that. I didn’t call or text her until about two or three days after she came back from Florida. I sent her a text asking when she would be available so I could come get my money. She said, "Well, unfortunately, you won’t be getting your money back because it’s nonrefundable. You decided not to go."

Judge: Was there an empty slot on the trip?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay, Karifa, what’s your version?

Defendant: Well, mostly everything she said was true. The book club started, and we had been planning this trip for a long time. I wanted it to be special because this was our first trip as a group. We saw her at our cousin’s dinner, and her response to us wasn’t that warm. She had been acting funny. At my mom’s salon, my sister said she wanted to go on the trip. I told her she couldn’t because it was for book club members only. She called Shade and asked to take her spot, and Shade said "Yeah."

Judge: Did you tell her you’d return her money?

Defendant: Yes, I did. I didn’t want bad blood. But she never called us, never arranged anything for the trip.

Judge: Did your sister go on the trip?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Okay, the text message. Can I see it?

Plaintiff: Yes, here.

Judge: If you tell her you’re returning her money, then you return her money. You admitted it anyway. You’re suing for $240, but you only gave her $200?

Plaintiff: Yes, the $40 is court costs.

Judge: I find in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $200 plus court costs. That’s my judgment. Good luck, folks.

Judge: Darius, you are suing Barbara for $3,779 that you say you gave her to hold for you while you were in prison and she spent on herself. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Darius): Well, Your Honor, I was currently incarcerated, and I received a settlement.

Judge: While you were incarcerated?

Plaintiff: While I was incarcerated, I bailed myself out with the settlement. I worked it out where I posted my bail, and when I was released, I didn’t have any identification. So, as a courtesy from the lawyer who litigated the matter, I asked him to place a check in my niece’s name because she would cash it for me.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: And she placed the check in her account. She cashed it for me.

Judge: How much was the total?

Plaintiff: The total check was $9,779.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Plaintiff: And the day the check cleared, I was remanded again on the same case.

Judge: Wait, I don’t understand. You bailed out, right?

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor.

Judge: Then why did they take you back in?

Plaintiff: They took me back in because there was a dispute between an attorney—

Judge: No, no, no. I was a criminal lawyer. I know when people get remanded. Did you pick up another case?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Did you violate the conditions of your bail?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Then they can’t just drag a guy back in after he’s posted bail and say, “Yeah, we changed our mind.” That doesn’t happen. What actually happened?

Plaintiff: It happened, Your Honor. And, to go small in depth and in detail of it, I hired an attorney. The attorney went to the appellate division, and the bail was reversed.

Judge: Why?

Plaintiff: And I could post bail again, but my niece had my money, and she wouldn’t bail me out.

Judge: That doesn’t make any sense. There had to be something else. You had to have violated a condition, or there was a new case filed, or it was a probation violation. Something had to be going on that would allow that. But anyway, let’s move on. So, you gave her $9,779 to hold in her account?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then, do you take any of it for lawyer’s fees?

Plaintiff: I asked my niece to find an attorney for me. She found an attorney for me, and I have a copy of the retainer.

Judge: Not detainer—retainer.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And the retainer was how much?

Plaintiff: The retainer was $5,000.

Judge: So that’s how much of the money you have used.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So, you got a new lawyer. And then, do you end up going to trial?

Plaintiff: Yes, I ended up going to trial.

Judge: And you got convicted?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What was the charge?

Plaintiff: Possession of stolen property.

Judge: And you ended up going to jail for how long?

Plaintiff: I spent four and a half years.

Judge: Four and a half years. And the first lawyer was trying to get you to take a plea deal?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What was the plea offer?

Plaintiff: One to three years.

Judge: Okay, but you know, don’t feel bad about that because it’s always a gamble. You might have walked. You know your case better than anybody else. You may feel bad about it, maybe you should feel bad about it, I don’t know. But I’m not judging you because everybody’s master of their own destiny.

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor.

Judge: All right. So, during that time, the remaining $4,779 is in her account?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then you get out. What happens?

Plaintiff: During the course of my incarceration, I needed more money for my legal fees for my attorney to go to trial. After the bail was reinstated by the appellate division, a bond could have been posted so I could get back out. The attorney tried several times to reach out to her to bail me out, and we never heard from her again.

Judge: She’s your niece, right?

Plaintiff: Yes, she’s my niece.

Judge: How is she your niece?

Plaintiff: She’s my brother’s daughter.

Judge: Right. So when you say you never heard from her—did you call your brother? Did you have the lawyer call your brother?

Plaintiff: My brother is deceased. I wrote everyone I possibly could to try to get her to do something for me—post my bail, help me.

Judge: So what ended up happening?

Plaintiff: After I was released, I came home and asked for my money. She gave me $1,000 of the money.

Judge: And the remainder? What did she say about the rest?

Plaintiff: She said she wasn’t giving it to me.

Judge: Why?

Plaintiff: She didn’t say why.

Judge: If she said she didn’t owe you anything, why did she give you the $1,000?

Plaintiff: I don’t know, Your Honor.

Judge: What did she say when she gave you the $1,000?

Plaintiff: She told me I wasn’t getting any more money from her.

Judge: Okay. Defendant, tell me what happened.

Defendant (Barbara): My uncle came home in June, and he had a lawsuit settlement for $9,779.

Judge: That amount was put in your account?

Defendant: Correct. $5,000 of it went to his lawyer years ago.

Judge: So that means there was an additional $4,779 in your account.

Defendant: He never told me it was a loan. He knew he was going away. He told me to make sure I took care of the family, and that’s what I did.

Judge: How does “take care of the family” translate to spending his money?

Defendant: I took care of the family—my son, my mother, and his nephew.

Judge: Did he tell you to give $1,000 to his nephew?

Defendant: Yes.

Plaintiff: No, Your Honor.

Judge: What did you say to her?

Plaintiff: I told her to use it but put it back.

Judge: Do you have proof of what he said?

Defendant: No, it’s just his word against mine.

Judge: When the plaintiff comes to court, he has the burden of proof. But in this case, there’s no dispute that the money was his. You’re the one who must prove it was a gift.

Defendant: I gave him $1,000 because he had no money, no place to sleep.

Judge: Why would you do that if it was a gift?

Defendant: I was just helping.

Judge: My verdict is for the plaintiff in the amount of $3,779.

Judge: This is the plaintiff Shaita Barnes. She says she was going to rent an apartment from the defendant, and as it turns out, the thing was a fire trap.
Judge: Shaita Barnes, you are suing your former landlord, Felix Figueroa, for $1,880 in security deposits, rent that you paid, and moving services because you found out that the place was an illegal sublet. Tell me what’s going on.
Plaintiff: Just to start, I signed the lease with Felix and my witness, Loreno Richards, on October 23rd of 2012. That was a Wednesday. He allowed me to start moving things in earlier, but due to Hurricane Sandy, I didn’t physically spend the night in the apartment until Friday, November 2nd. Four days after being in the apartment, my girlfriend, Loreno, was coming over. I went to open the door for her, and when I did—
Judge: Does she live there with you? Is she your roommate?
Plaintiff: No, she’s my girlfriend.
Judge: Okay. So, she’s not on the lease?
Plaintiff: No, absolutely not.
Judge: Do you have the lease with you?
Plaintiff: I do.
Judge: Okay. So, she comes over. What happens?
Plaintiff: The type of lock that Felix had on the door, it’s the same key that you use to get in that you use to get out. You have to lock the door from the inside. So, I'm on the phone with her, trying to open the door, and I’m thinking, "I must be bugging," because I had only been in the apartment for four days. I’m thinking, "I must have the wrong key." Felix left the keys on the window sill for me when I moved in. She says, "Throw the keys down."
Judge: Is that the first time you had needed to open and close the door?
Plaintiff: No, it had worked before. But that night, it wouldn’t open. It was really dark outside. I had a flashlight, threw the keys down to her, she came up through the back—because there was only one entrance, no front entrance—and she wasn’t able to open the door.
Judge: What kind of place were you renting? A basement?
Plaintiff: It was a third-floor attic.
Judge: An attic. Did you have your own entrance and exit?
Plaintiff: The same way you got into the apartment was the only entrance and exit.
Judge: Okay. So, now what do you do? Does he live there too?
Plaintiff: He does. Felix lives on the first floor.
Judge: So, you go downstairs, knock on his door, and tell him what?
Plaintiff: I tell him she can’t get out of the apartment. So, she’s locked in her own apartment.
Judge: Got it. So, what happens next?
Plaintiff: He comes upstairs, tries to jig the door, and he can’t get it open. He goes downstairs, gets a hammer, and tries to open it. Then he goes back down and gets something else, like a flathead screwdriver.
Judge: At this point, how long had you been living there?
Plaintiff: Four days.
Judge: And then one of you starts taking video?
Plaintiff: I took a video just to see how long it would take. We tried for at least 30 minutes before he managed to open it with the screwdriver.
Judge: Was there a fire escape?
Plaintiff: No.
Judge: You came up, tried to open the door. What was wrong with it?
Defendant: The cylinder lock wasn’t working properly. After we opened it, I noticed someone must have tampered with it.
Judge: How can someone tamper with a lock they’re using as intended?
Defendant: The deadbolt and the regular lock use the same key. Somehow, the mechanism wouldn’t retract.
Judge: So, you forced it open with a screwdriver?
Defendant: Yes.
Judge: That’s not how doors are supposed to work.
Plaintiff: That’s what got me thinking. I have asthma. I also remembered a news story about a fire where firefighters couldn’t rescue people from a third floor because there was only one exit. So, I called Bridgeport Zoning. They told me the house had always been listed as a two-family house.
Judge: Do you have a Certificate of Occupancy for the attic?
Defendant: No.
Judge: Then you rented out an illegal apartment. That means you cannot collect rent. You cannot keep security deposits for damages you did not claim. You cannot charge a pet deposit. You owe her back the security deposit, pet deposit, and any additional money for the last month's rent. That totals $1,200.
Plaintiff: I also paid moving fees in and out of the apartment.
Judge: You would have paid for moving out of your last apartment anyway. I will award you the moving-out cost, bringing the total to $1,540. Verdict for the plaintiff.
Defendant: Understood.
Plaintiff: Thank you.

Defendant: "Well... it was a one-night stand. I haven't... you know, I haven't heard from her in months. You know, and then she comes telling me that, you know, she's pregnant and she's having a baby. Then she says she wanted to be my baby and all that type of stuff. I told her, 'Look, I love my wife, I love my family, my kids. I just want to move on. Get this thing behind me.'"
Judge: "So... Let me be clear, you say this only happened, this one night?"
Defendant: "Just one night."
Judge: "You never saw her again?"
Defendant: "Never saw her again."
Judge: "That's wrong, Your Honor. That's wrong."
Defendant: "Well... we did sleep around a couple of times."
Judge: "So, it was more than one night?"
Defendant: "Yes. She's just looking for some money. She's looking for a cash-out."

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff says Sunny was on a leash when the defendant's dog viciously attacked, but the defendant says the plaintiff's dog was the aggressor. It's the case of Sunny Side Up. Thank you, Douglas. Sueellen Kemp, you are suing Amy Heckler for $515 in vet bills when, according to you, her dog, unleashed, attacked your dog.

Plaintiff: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: Yes, your honor. Um, it was March 8th, a nice evening, about 9:30 at night, and I was taking my dog for our little evening walk. We were taking a short walk that night. So we were just walking down our street, which was about two blocks. We took a turn in front of Amy's house, and at that time—

Judge: Did you two know each other before this?

Plaintiff: No, ma'am.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: I have lived on Sunset Beach now for five years, and I did not know her. Did not know her at that time. So anyway, I was out walking my dog, and we turned the corner to do our short walk. Sunny was on my right side, and as we were going down that street, all of a sudden, this dog comes out from nowhere and all of a sudden he's attacking my dog. I look up and I say, "Is that your dog?" She says, "Yes." I said, "Oh, you know, please help me! Help me!" At that point, my dog was down on the ground. All I could see was a square head of a dog, and then I just didn't know what to do. I couldn't pull my dog off. Amy—now I know her name—couldn't pull her dog off. And all of a sudden, I guess Amy fell down. All I could do was start to scream for help because there were people watching what was going on.

Judge: Why couldn't you guys pull the dogs off?

Plaintiff: Because my dog was down on the ground being attacked.

Judge: No, but I'm saying that you physically couldn't—listen to my question. She physically couldn't handle the weight of her dog and physically wasn't strong enough to pull him off? Or nobody wanted to pull him off because he had your dog by the—I'm not following what you're saying.

Plaintiff: Yes, your honor. She was trying to pull him off but physically couldn't handle it.

Judge: All right, then you caught the attention of a couple of teenagers?

Plaintiff: Exactly, teenage boys, yes.

Judge: What happened?

Plaintiff: They came around. They could hear me screaming. They could hear the dog fight. So they came around, and they saw what was going on. They took the leash out of my hand—I still had Sunny's leash in my hand—and then they broke the fight up.

Judge: Okay. And then we all dispersed and went our own ways. Did you think that there were no injuries to your dog at the time?

Plaintiff: At that point, he was able to walk away. I didn't see any blood.

Judge: So you thought it was going to be okay.

Plaintiff: I thought it was going to be okay.

Judge: As it turned out, it wasn’t, though, right?

Plaintiff: That is correct.

Judge: How many days passed before you realized that your dog was injured?

Plaintiff: This was Thursday evening. Then on Saturday morning, I had my friend Bob, who lives on the corner from me, come by and check on my dog during the day. He was shaking his head, shaking his head, and just out of balance. Bob called me at work and said, "Sunny needs to go see the vet." So I said okay. This was on a Saturday, so my veterinarian was closed, and they said I should go to the emergency clinic, which I did as soon as I got off work that night.

Judge: And then, as it turned out, Sunny needed stitches in his ear.

Plaintiff: That's correct.

Judge: Okay, now, Amy, tell me your side of this.

Defendant: At first, I didn’t even know who she was. It was a week later that I heard from her.

Judge: But you remember a week ago when there was a dog fight?

Defendant: I knew what happened, but—

Judge: What was your dog doing?

Defendant: My dog wasn’t really loose. We have a porch, and I was sitting there. He was on the porch with me.

Judge: Loose? Unleashed?

Defendant: Yes, but he was with me.

Judge: That means he wasn’t under control, though.

Defendant: He’s never come off the porch before.

Judge: But he did this time, right? That’s the problem. The law requires you to have full control of your dog at all times.

Defendant: I grabbed his harness immediately, but the other dog was right there.

Judge: Florida is a strict liability state for dog attacks. That means you are responsible for the actions of your dog, period. You pay the vet bill. $515, judgment for the plaintiff.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiffs say the defendant ripped them off in a real estate deal, but the defendant says no way—the plaintiff found another house and he's entitled to the money she paid him. It’s the case of Your Real Estate Is Unreal.

Judge: Lorraine Peters and Vashy White, you are suing Sugrim Jagay for $3,487. $2,500 of it is a deposit that you claim he won’t return. The rest includes lawyer’s fees, interest, and prepaid phone cards for calling Guyana. You want him to pay for those now that the deal has fallen through. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: Mr. Jagay was selling a property back in Guyana.

Judge: Are both sides from Guyana?

Plaintiff: Yes, and we decided to purchase the property.

Judge: I’m a little bit confused—who owns the property, you or the government?

Defendant: I own the property, but it was leased to us from the government.

Judge: Wait a minute. How do you own the property if it’s leased to you by the government?

Defendant: I own the house, but the land belongs to the government.

Judge: Okay. So what were you selling her, the house?

Defendant: The house and the land.

Judge: But how do you sell the land if you don’t own it?

Defendant: We can transfer it. That’s part of the contract.

Judge: So apparently, you two understand the process—I’m the only one who doesn’t. When the lease is up, they have to enter into another lease with the government?

Defendant: Yes, eventually, they give us a lease, and then we get title to it.

Judge: So at the end of the lease term, whoever owns the physical building owns the land as well?

Defendant: Right.

Judge: In the meantime, do you make payments to the government on the lease?

Defendant: No, we pay to the local authority.

Judge: But you do pay something?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay. So you were going to buy a house in Guyana that he was selling. How much was it?

Plaintiff: $60,000.

Judge: U.S. dollars?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Do you have a contract?

Plaintiff: Yes, we entered into an agreement.

Judge: This contract was entered into in 2006?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: The contract specifies that possession of the property will be delivered on or before August 1st. The vendor—that’s you, Mr. Jagay—shall transfer title to the purchasers within three months of the date of the determination of the application for approval of transfer of title.

Judge: Where does it state how long it will take for the government of Guyana to approve the transfer?

Plaintiff: The problem is that it didn’t happen in the time allotted.

Judge: You entered into a contract to buy a piece of property in Guyana for $60,000 on April 29th. Why do you want your money back?

Plaintiff: I didn’t hear from Mr. Jagay until I wrote him a letter in August of 2006. I made several phone calls, but no response. Then I sent a registered letter, and that’s when I heard from him.

Judge: You had his phone number?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What happened when you called him?

Plaintiff: It went to voicemail, and he didn’t call me back.

Judge: And you left messages?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So what did the letter say?

Plaintiff: That we made an agreement for the purchase, and I wasn’t hearing anything from him. My ex-husband didn’t hear anything from his power of attorney in Guyana. It had been over three months.

Judge: As I understand it, the sale was approved in late August 2006. Two weeks after your letter, he sent you a photocopy.

Plaintiff: Yes, but my relatives in Guyana were never informed.

Judge: Mr. Jagay, after the property was approved, how did you notify her?

Defendant: My niece informed her husband, and he told her.

Judge: When was this?

Defendant: Early September, about three or four days after the approval.

Judge: And what did she say?

Defendant: She told me they were no longer interested in buying the property. They had purchased another house.

Judge: Is that true?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Defendant: I had already spent nearly $2,000 in property valuation and processing fees. I agreed to refund half of their advance, but they refused.

Judge: That may not have been a good idea. Where in the contract does it state that if the deal is not completed in three months, she gets her money back?

Plaintiff: It was a verbal agreement.

Judge: That’s a problem. You can’t verbally change a written agreement.

Plaintiff: The Ministry of Agriculture told me there was no paperwork.

Judge: But I see paperwork. He has proof. You’re saying you never received it?

Plaintiff: No, we never got any paperwork.

Defendant: I gave it to her husband.

Judge: There was a meeting with lawyers in September where this was discussed?

Defendant: Yes, in their presence. They demanded their money back. They had already bought another property.

Judge: Make sure she gets a copy. My verdict is for the defendant.

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Terrence Rush. He says he's in the vending machine business, and the defendant has three of his machines and refuses to return them. The defendant has no right to keep the machines. He knows the judge will side with him today and is suing him for their value, which is $4,000.

This is the defendant, Gregory Brent. He says he and the plaintiff were supposed to split the income from their machines, and when the plaintiff came to collect the money from him, he didn’t give him his portion. His store is located across the street from a school. He generates a lot of money and wants his split.

He’s accused of playing games, but the defendant has filed a countersuit for $600, the loss of income he was owed.

All parties, your radiance. Welcome back to The People’s Court.

Next case on the docket: The plaintiff rented out vending machines. The defendant got three of them and won’t return them. But the defendant says they were supposed to split the income from the machines, and the plaintiff stiffed him.

It’s the case of "Sure Plays a Mean Gumball."

Thank you, DC.

All right, TNT Vending, represented by Mr. Rush, is suing K&J Wireless and GM Food Mart, represented by Mr. Brent, for $4,000, the value of some machines that you say you had a contract with him for to leave in there, that belonged to you, and you don’t see them anymore.

And you have a counterclaim for loss of income from those same machines.

Okay, first, let’s discuss what the agreement was between you two.

Judge: You have a series of vending machines. What kind of machines are they that are in his place?

Plaintiff: There is a tabletop arcade video game.

Judge: And which game?

Plaintiff: Pac-Man.

Judge: Pac-Man? Did that make a comeback? And what else?

Plaintiff: There is also a sucker machine.

Judge: A what?

Plaintiff: It’s called a sucker—like a lollipop. It’s a sucker machine.

Judge: How does that machine work?

Plaintiff: You put a quarter in the machine, and the sucker rotates around and falls down.

Judge: Oh, okay. So, a lollipop machine. Not a lot of challenge in that one. And what else?

Plaintiff: And there was also a gumball machine.

Judge: Okay, I know how those work. So those are the three machines. And then you entered into a contract with him. Is the contract in writing?

Plaintiff: Yes, it is.

Judge: May I see it?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How long has the contract been in effect?

Plaintiff: Two years.

Judge: All right, and the contract says that he lets you put your machines there and the two of you split the proceeds from the machines, right?

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: Okay, so on the gumball and the lollipop machine, he gets 30%, and you get 70%.

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: And on the game machine, he gets 50%, and you get 50%.

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: It worked well until when? When did things start going poorly?

Plaintiff: Things started going down as of December of 2017.

Judge: Oh, right away. So, it didn’t work very well at all. In December, what happens?

Plaintiff: The profits started going down.

Judge: Going down from what? It had only been around for two months.

Plaintiff: I do have receipts showing when I give him a copy of it, that I get a copy of what comes out of the machine.

Judge: How does it work? You physically go there, and then the quarters are counted in front of both parties?

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: Would you go in weekly?

Plaintiff: I go in, um, usually once a month.

Judge: So at the end of October, you got a reading, then the end of November, it was less, and the end of December, it was even less?

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: Why is that a problem with him? He has every incentive, just like you, to want more quarters.

Plaintiff: That’s correct, Your Honor, but the business was not open every day at certain hours.

Judge: Where does your contract say how long he has to be open?

Plaintiff: It doesn’t state how long.

Judge: You don’t control when he opens and closes.

Plaintiff: I understand that, Your Honor, but what I’m saying is that it was not open to the public.

Judge: I understand exactly what you’re saying. If you want him to be open 40 hours a week, you need to put that in your contract. Otherwise, he opens and closes whenever the heck he wants. It’s his business.

But in any event, you notice that the profits are down. How much are they down? How much were you getting a month at first?

Plaintiff: As I stated here—

Judge: Let me see that.

Plaintiff: Here you go.

Judge: Thank you. So, the first time you checked at the end of October, the total amount from the video game was $62, so you gave him $31. The total amount at the end of November for the tabletop video game was $47, so you gave him $23. Then, the total amount in December was $33, and you gave him $16. The gumball machine made $6.

Okay, they’re not doing that well. Go on.

Plaintiff: I stopped by to see if someone was there—no answer. No one was at the business. It had a board in front of it.

Judge: Did you ever say, "I want to take my machines out because you’re not open enough"?

Plaintiff: That’s correct, I did.

Judge: When did you say that?

Plaintiff: Some time went by, in August.

Judge: Are you telling me that for eight months, you weren’t able to get in there?

Plaintiff: That’s correct, because it was always closed.

Judge: Have you been closed for eight months?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Have you been closed at all for any reason?

Defendant: Sometimes in the morning, I don’t open because the school’s not out. The traffic for everything is the high schoolers. So after 2 o’clock, that’s when we’re mainly open.

Judge: Have you received any money from these machines since December of 2017?

Defendant: No, because I was in and out of the hospital.
Judge: What were you in the hospital for?

Defendant: I had a medical condition, so I was in and out for about four or five months.

Judge: Were you operating the store at all during that time?

Defendant: No, I wasn’t. My son was helping to run it part-time.

Judge: When was the last time the plaintiff was able to access the machines?

Plaintiff: August 2018.

Judge: And what happened when you tried to get them?

Plaintiff: The business was locked. No one was answering my calls. I had no way to retrieve my machines.

Judge: So, at what point did you officially request to remove them?

Plaintiff: Around that time, I told him I wanted my machines back, but I wasn’t able to get them.

Judge: Did you ever refuse to return them?

Defendant: No, I didn’t refuse. He never formally requested them back in writing.

Judge: Do you still have the machines?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Where are they?

Defendant: I had to move locations, and when I moved, the machines were taken by the property owner.

Judge: Why would the property owner take machines that don’t belong to you?

Defendant: Because I owed rent, and when I couldn’t pay, the landlord took possession of things left in the store.

Judge: Did you tell the landlord the machines didn’t belong to you?

Defendant: No, because I wasn’t there when they were taken.

Judge: So, you lost his machines as part of an eviction process?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Why didn’t you notify the plaintiff that his machines were in jeopardy?

Defendant: I wasn’t thinking about that at the time, Your Honor.

Judge: That’s a problem. These machines didn’t belong to you, and you allowed them to be taken. So, you are responsible for their loss.

Defendant: I understand, but he also wasn’t paying me my share of the profits fairly.

Judge: That’s your counterclaim, right? That you were owed money from the profits?

Defendant: Yes, I believe I was owed at least $600 over time.

Judge: Based on the records, the income from these machines was declining steadily. There was never a time where you were owed anything close to $600 in missing payments. Your counterclaim is denied.

Judge: As for the plaintiff’s claim, these machines were lost due to the defendant’s negligence. You are responsible for their replacement value.

Plaintiff: Thank you, Your Honor.

Judge: Judgment in favor of the plaintiff for $4,000. Case dismissed.

**Judge:** This is the plaintiff, Raymond Event. He says he bought a truck from the defendant, and when he went to start it up and drive it off her property, it wouldn't start. All parties, please raise your right hands.

**Judge:** Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff bought a truck from the defendant, and it was in such bad shape that he had to push it off her property. But the defendant says it was an old truck, and he took his chances. It's the case of "Truck You."

Thank you, Douglas. Raymond Havent, you are suing Debra Rebecca Dixon for $850 that you paid for a truck. Plus, you want the money you paid the mechanic to look at the truck back, so a total of $1,000, because according to you, she violated the Lemon Law. Okay, tell me what happened.

**Plaintiff:** Okay, I met this lady here back in—uh, doing volunteer work. So I delivered a refrigerator to her house. That's how I met her. She had a nice truck in the yard. I can show you pictures of it.

**Judge:** She had what?

**Plaintiff:** A nice truck.

**Judge:** A nice truck in the yard. Can I see the pictures?

**Plaintiff:** Yes. I love these trucks too. They're good trucks.

**Judge:** Uh-huh. What year was the truck?

**Plaintiff:** 2001.

**Judge:** 2001, and it was what?

**Plaintiff:** Ford Expedition.

**Judge:** Expedition. I used to have one of those. Okay, go on.

**Plaintiff:** So, uh, I asked her what was wrong with it. She said it kept cutting off, and she got tired of putting gas in it because it kept cutting off.

**Judge:** When you asked her what was wrong with it, she said it kept cutting off, and she was tired of putting gas in it?

**Plaintiff:** Right.

**Judge:** Oh, that pesky little detail. Cars where you have to keep putting gas in them, right?

**Plaintiff:** But see, I thought just cutting off had to be something simple, like the gas or—

**Judge:** Why would it be something simple? It could be something horrible.

**Plaintiff:** No, but—

**Judge:** And why are you going to trust her? Does she look like a car mechanic to you?

**Plaintiff:** No, but she said it was just cutting off. That’s what I went by. But she should have told me the engine was locked up in it.

**Judge:** How's she going to know that?

**Plaintiff:** She knew. Anytime you drive a vehicle and sell it, you know what’s wrong.

**Judge:** Was she driving that vehicle?

**Plaintiff:** Well, she drove it to her house in a part of New York.

**Judge:** When was the last time she had driven the vehicle?

**Plaintiff:** Oh—

**Judge:** When was the last time she had driven the vehicle?

**Plaintiff:** She never told me she really did.

**Judge:** Okay. Now let me hear your version of this, which is exceedingly different.

**Defendant:** Approximately right after Christmas of 2017, my refrigerator started malfunctioning. So, my sister and I, we lived together, and we needed a new one. Mr. Raymond was the driver of the delivery truck that brought us the refrigerator—him and his coworker.

**Judge:** Okay.

**Defendant:** And he saw the vehicle in the yard and asked me if it was for sale. It had been sitting there for four years. I said, "Sure." He asked me how much, and I had read the Blue Book and everything before. It was like $700 to $1,000. Since I didn’t know what was wrong with it, I said the highest price.

**Judge:** Okay.

**Defendant:** And, um, Mr. Raymond, he came over two or three times a month. He called too many times a month after the fact.

**Judge:** Why?

**Defendant:** To explain to me why he didn’t have the money, that he would have the money, that he was in an accident.

**Judge:** Did he want you to sell it to someone else?

**Defendant:** No, right. But he never had the money.

**Judge:** How much later did he come up with the money?

**Defendant:** October.

**Judge:** Okay, so we’re talking about ten months of him calling you, saying, "Is it still there? Is it still there?"

**Defendant:** Right.

**Judge:** Then what happens?

**Defendant:** He kept coming and visiting and just coming to look at the vehicle. My brother would tell me, "He’s out there again."

**Judge:** Did he ever ask for the keys to try to start it up?

**Defendant:** I told him I did not want him to work on the vehicle in the yard.

**Judge:** That’s not working on the vehicle. You never asked for the keys to start it up?

**Plaintiff:** I gave him the keys to open the vehicle and look.

**Judge:** Okay, why didn’t you just try to start it?

**Plaintiff:** The reason why it wouldn’t start was because the battery was dead.

**Judge:** Oh, so you did try to start it up, but it wouldn’t start. So you figured, "Oh, no problem, I’ll buy the car anyway." Rather than having a mechanic look at it before you paid for the car, you decided, "I want the car." You negotiated a price of $850, and you handed her $850, and she handed you a bill of sale that says: "I, Debra Dixon, grant sale of the Ford Expedition 2001." It has a VIN number and it says, "As is."

What did you think "as is" meant?

**Plaintiff:** "As is," but I didn’t think—

**Judge:** Does it mean you get to come to court and sue her and say, "You didn’t tell me this thing was a piece of garbage"?

**Plaintiff:** I thought I was going to have a good set of wheels for $850.

**Judge:** It’s an "as is" sale. It’s buyer beware. You should have had a mechanic take a look at it beforehand. That’s my verdict. Good luck, folks.

Judge:

Judge:
All parties please raise your right hands. You may be seated. Thank you. Mr. Tillman, what’s going on?

Well, your honor, I met this young lady on a bus ride to the Sands in Pennsylvania, which is a casino. After that, once we came back home, I heard from her again. She told me her car was pulled over and that she had to go to the DMV to renew her driver’s license and registration because they were suspended. Judge:
So you loaned her how much?

$200, and I put it in writing. The $200 was going to become $535 if she didn’t pay me back on time.

When was the loan made?

Plaintiff (Wallace Tillman):
On February 5th.

Judge:
And when was it supposed to be paid back?

Plaintiff (Wallace Tillman):
By February 8th.

Defendant (Sandra):
No, I didn’t have the money that day. I texted him and told him I couldn’t give him the money before work, but I would have it later.

Plaintiff (Wallace Tillman):
She didn’t have the money on February 5th, and she didn’t have it when we saw each other on the bus. She lied and said she would give it to me after the bus ride, but when I went to meet her, she still didn’t have it.

Defendant (Sandra):
I didn’t have the cash at the time, but I told him I would get it later. I tried to pay him, but when I gave him the money, he said he wanted to go to a hotel room and have sex instead of getting the $200.

That’s not true. I never asked her for that. I asked for my $200. She kept avoiding me.

What happened when you met at the casino?

Defendant (Sandra):
When we met, I gave him the $200. But he told me that he and the bus driver had rented two rooms upstairs and said he wanted to go upstairs and have sex with me instead of taking the money. I refused, and I walked off.

Defendant (Sandra):
Yes, I did. He propositioned me, and I didn’t appreciate it.

After I didn’t get the money, I went looking for her with the bus driver. We finally found her at the casino. I asked for my money again, and she got upset. She didn’t want to pay me. That’s when I said I was adding extra fees.

That’s not true. He never told me he was adding extra fees. He just kept insisting I should give him the money.

Let’s take a look at the texts. It appears there was quite a bit of communication. (Judge looks at text messages on the phone.) Defendant (Sandra):
I was upset, but I couldn’t bring it up in the texts. My phone was broken, and I couldn’t retrieve all the texts.

But you didn’t mention anything about him propositioning you in these texts, even though that’s your defense. You should have texted him, saying how dare you proposition me, but you didn’t. Instead, your texts just ask about paying back the money.

Defendant (Sandra):
I didn’t feel it was the right time to mention it. But I’m not a prostitute, and I didn’t want to give him anything after that.

Judge:
I’m not feeling much sympathy for you right now. You lied about the money, and you lied about the sexual proposition. I believe you owe him $525, which includes the $200 loan and the extra fees you agreed to.

Plaintiff (Wallace Tillman):
Thank you, your honor. I’m glad this is over.

Judge:
$525 for the plaintiff, plus court costs. This is what happens when a $200 problem becomes a bigger issue.

Defendant (Sandra):

Judge: You can’t sue for slander over statements made in a lawsuit. Your counterclaim is dismissed. As for your claim for $4,950, thanks for the chuckle, but no. You do get your security deposit back. Judgment for the plaintiff.

Judge:
Daniel Benal, you are suing Homero Zapata for $5,000, the amount you paid for a vehicle that you claim you never got a valid title for. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff:
Your Honor, around June 18th, a mutual friend named Anthony facilitated an exchange. I traded a watch I paid $7,000 for in exchange for the defendant’s car, which he was selling for $5,000.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
At the time, I was living in Massachusetts. It’s impossible to live there without a car—I couldn't get a job, etc.

Judge:
What made you move to Massachusetts if you didn’t already have a job?

Plaintiff:
I did have a job lined up, but I couldn’t take it without a car.

Judge:
Who proposed this trade?

Plaintiff:
It was my idea.

Judge:
What kind of watch was it?

Plaintiff:
A Chopard Grand Prix Del Monaco. Limited edition. There are 500 in the world.

Judge:
Why didn’t you just sell the watch, keep two grand, and buy the car?

Plaintiff:
The resale value fluctuates depending on whether you have the box and papers. A barter was easier.

Judge:
Okay, so the car gets delivered to you how?

Plaintiff:
July 2nd. The defendant drove it up to Massachusetts.

Judge:
Who did you give the car to?

Defendant:
I drove it up and gave it to him directly. I already had the watch before that.

Judge:
So he just gave you the watch before even getting the car?

Defendant:
Yes. He trusted Anthony, and Anthony trusted me.

Judge:
Then what happened?

Plaintiff:
I went to register the car at the DMV that week. They told me the title was defective. I have a copy here. The car was registered to someone named Timothy, not the defendant.

Judge:
Who is Timothy?

Defendant:
I bought the car at an auction. I planned to buy it for a relative.

Judge:
Did you ever register the car in your name?

Defendant:
No, ma’am.

Judge:
So Timothy signed over the title?

Defendant:
Yes, but there were cross-outs, and I was misinformed. I thought I could sign it over directly. I didn’t know.

Judge:
So, plaintiff, you went to the DMV, and they wouldn’t accept it?

Plaintiff:
Correct. Over the next few weeks, I tried to sort it out with the defendant.

Judge:
Defendant, when did the plaintiff first notify you?

Defendant:
August 7th.

Judge:
Why the delay, plaintiff?

Plaintiff:
I had been going back and forth with the DMV.

Judge:
I don’t buy that. I think you waited a month. So, what did you do next, defendant?

Defendant:
He mailed me the title. I received it on August 13th. The next day, I went to the DMV to fix it. They told me it would take six to eight weeks. I told the plaintiff, and he was okay with it.

Judge:
Did the new title come?

Defendant:
Yes, on October 11th.

Judge:
When did you inform the plaintiff?

Defendant:
October 12th. I texted him. He never responded.

Judge:
Plaintiff, when did you file this lawsuit?

Plaintiff:
Before I heard from him.

Judge:
Where is the car now?

Plaintiff:
Still in Massachusetts, parked in Anthony’s backyard.

Judge:
So here’s how this works. When you sell a car, you’re supposed to provide a good title. The plaintiff went to the DMV and couldn't register the car. The defendant then cooperated fully and did everything he was supposed to do. He fixed the title issue as soon as he got the paperwork from the plaintiff.

Judge:
The delay between August 14th and October 12th was due to the DMV. That’s not the defendant’s fault. You agreed to wait for the new title. By the time he got it, you had changed your mind. But you can’t just undo the deal because of a DMV delay you knew would happen.

Judge:
This is your car, plaintiff. Do you have the title, defendant?

Defendant:
Yes, ma’am.

Judge:
Hand it over. Did you sign it in the right place this time?

Defendant:
Not yet.

Judge:
Good. I’ll make sure this is transferred correctly.

Verdict for the defendant.

Plaintiff's Lawyer: Thank you, Your Honor, and may it please the Court. The question presented is narrow: Should courts apply Mathews or Barker to assess the sufficiency of process in civil forfeiture proceedings? The answer is Mathews.

Mathews is the default due process standard for civil cases and for good reason. It assesses both the private and governmental interests to guard against unreasonable risks of error. The Court has consistently applied it to determine whether more process is due, including in Good, another civil forfeiture case.

The opposing side prefers Barker because Barker's answer is always no additional process. But their primary argument is just that $8,850 and Von Neumann already decided the question, not that Barker makes sense and Mathews doesn't. They are wrong. As the Second and Sixth Circuits have explained in adopting Mathews over Barker, $8,850 and Von Neumann concern the length of time for a final disposition rather than the need for an interim hearing.

Only Mathews can answer the sufficiency of process question. The courts of appeals and state supreme courts that have addressed the question have overwhelmingly chosen Mathews over Barker. The point of Mathews is to ensure that laws adequately protect the Constitution's fundamental due process guarantee, taking into account the private and governmental interests at stake. It's not to micromanage state legislatures.

The easiest way for a jurisdiction to ensure its laws comport with due process, as the Second and Sixth Circuits have explained, is generally to offer a reasonably prompt post-seizure hearing to allow claimants to raise an innocent owner argument. Numerous states have done just that, and their experience makes clear that retention hearings are workable and effective. I welcome the Court's questions.

Judge: Before we get to the choice between Barker and Mathews, isn’t there an antecedent question as to whether or not there’s any constitutional requirement for additional hearings in the context of forfeiture?

Plaintiff's Lawyer: Your Honor, I think that question is what Barker or Mathews, depending on which test this Court would choose, is meant to answer.

Judge: The reason I ask is because you seem to assume that an additional hearing is required.

Plaintiff's Lawyer: We’re not assuming that an additional hearing is required. We’re saying that Mathews is the way to analyze whether an additional hearing is required. The -- the point is --

Number two --

Judge Matheson's dissent and his boomerang theory of finality --

Judge: Bad facts make bad law, and I fear we may be headed that way. We know there are abuses of the forfeiture system. That's what we're doing, isn't it?

Judge: Could I just ask you to clarify that? Because I was confused when I read your brief about how exactly you want Mathews v. Eldridge to work, whether you want it to be a determination in each individual case as to whether, under the Mathews factors, a retention hearing is required, or whether Mathews operates to set up certain categorical rules, and, if so, what those categorical rules are. Are they likely to be state-by-state rules? How does Mathews work in this context?

Defendant’s Lawyer: The categorical level at which I think Mathews applies, it would make sense to think of it about car owners in jurisdictions with an innocent owner defense. I think that’s the level at which it applies.

Defendant’s Lawyer: But it’s not a nationwide rule that would require a precise copy of Krimstock hearings in all 50 states. It would allow flexibility for states under Mathews to come up with different ways to potentially satisfy the due process guarantee.

Defendant’s Lawyer: Again, the question is, is there a due process question even to ask? And Mathews tells us that there is.

Judge: Just on that methodological question again, the other side, of course, emphasizes precedent, but they also say that what process is due can't just be a policy question. And they look at history and say that, historically, this kind of interim hearing has not been required by the federal government or the states. There have been lots of different approaches.

Judge: And they say that even today, Alabama is not an outlier. There are lots of different approaches in the states. The states' amicus brief really highlights this. So they say, if we went your way, we would be constitutionalizing a policy question that for over 200 years has been left with the states and the federal government, handled in different ways.

Judge: So I just want you to respond to that overarching theme that I think is in the Solicitor General's brief, in Alabama's brief, and the states' amicus brief.

Defendant’s Lawyer: If I could make two points in response to that.

So we're leaving room for flexibility.

Defendant’s Lawyer: The second point, with respect to history, I don't think the history provides a clear answer for us here. First, at common law, property could be forfeited regardless of whether the owner was innocent. The innocent owner defense is something that didn't exist at common law. And, again, that gives rise to new procedural protections.

Defendant’s Lawyer: Second, as one of the judges previously explained in a prior case, historical forfeiture laws were quite limited. They were limited to a few specific subject areas, like customs and piracy, where it made some sense to think about in rem proceedings. Civil forfeiture today bears little resemblance to that.

Defendant’s Lawyer: Additionally, at the founding, forfeiture proceedings had to move quickly. The Institute for Justice brief explains that courts had to rule within 14 days of the filing date at common law. And so, again, you didn't have this sort of question of months- or years-long delays.

Judge: Oh, okay.

Defendant’s Lawyer: And—

Judge: Well, keep going then. I don't want you to keep going forever, but—

[Laughter.]

Defendant’s Lawyer: The only last point I was going to make is that forfeiture at common law was also considered against a backdrop that the founders had of distrust to civil forfeiture generally based on what the British were doing before the revolution.

Judge: Well, I mean, I'll end it by just saying the early federal statutes seem somewhat inconsistent with that, but I'll leave that.

Judge: Last -- last question. I -- I'm totally sympathetic to the idea that there might be a necessity defense in these cases, and there's a footnote in your brief that indicates that in a lot of cases you could -- you could maybe bring advance preliminary injunctive action at least as individuals. Judge: You just said a minute ago that a lot of this is taken care of on the ground as a practical matter. And I think one of the questions is, who takes care of it on the ground? So I guess following up on the necessity question, given the line-drawing problems that we've been going through, if a state has a traditional necessity defense, won't that take care of most of the concerns, if not all, and, therefore, avoid the need for having to constitutionalize an area and have a federal judge superintend this rather than the local community, which you've emphasized many times working with the nonprofits and charitable and religious organizations, which is how it works in most places?

Defendant’s Lawyer: Well, I -- I think that the necessity defense at least traditionally has required a much stronger sense of urgency and imminence than -- than this. If states had a necessity defense and we knew that it was available in all of these places, but even in -- in Oregon, I think it's a case called Barrett, the Court said it's theoretically possible, but there was a remand for factual issues. So we don't -- we don't know at this point in time whether -- whether there is such a defense. And that's really not in the -- in the -- in the case here.

This comes up on an Eighth Amendment challenge without -- without reference to the necessity defense and, frankly, without reference to the new Oregon statute, which seems highly instructive in terms of time, manner, and place that jurisdictions, Grants Pass should examine.

But I -- I don't think we can -- I don't think the Court should put this core point about Robinson to one side because, in -- the possibility that in Oregon and maybe, you know, maybe no other place, I don't know about California law of necessity, maybe it would be taken care of. I think, at this point in time, that is too speculative to --

Judge: Well, usually we think about before constitutionalizing an area or extending a constitutional precedent, you might disagree with that characterization, but before doing that, we usually think about whether state law, local law already -- already achieves those purposes so that the federal courts aren't micromanaging homeless policy.

Defendant’s Lawyer: Yeah, no. For -- for the people actually dealing with it day to day, that is certainly true, the City, the law enforcement, the City liaisons, the nonprofits, but it's not true for the federal court. The federal court doesn't have to get into any of that.

The only time the federal court would get into it is when -- is if the core principle of Robinson was being disregarded by not -- by criminalizing somebody for sleeping outside when they have no place to sleep inside. That's the core principle. That's the only thing a court should be enforcing, not the -- not whether people -- whether people show up.

And the thing I would -- another thing I would say about the necessity defense, it -- it may be that if the Court issues an appropriate injunction in this case or another case limited to the core principle of Robinson, but it develops or the state law develops that there is a necessity defense, then I think that should be taken into account.

I mean, that's in effect the time, manner, and place or -- or similar to that. If state law comes -- comes along and establishes a -- a realistic defense or a realistic approach to how people can remain in the -- in the community, then the courts obviously should defer to that.

But we don't have that established state law at this time. And I don't think the Court should decline to address this question, which is important in the Ninth Circuit, both because the principle that those courts recognize should be sustained but the approach they've taken should not.

Judge: Last question I have on the food hypotheticals about stealing to feed yourself or cooking to feed yourself. Defendant’s Lawyer: No, it -- it doesn't always happen.

Judge: And then what?

Defendant’s Lawyer: But homeless people are resourceful. They have friends who are also homeless. They may -- they may know people in town. They may beg for money. Judge: Thank you.

Judge: So one odd thing about the posture of this case, putting aside the class part, is its pre-enforcement nature, because in Robinson and in Powell too, the punishment -- you know, the -- the adjudication of guilt had already occurred and it was time for the punishment to be imposed, and then the Eighth Amendment challenge was raised.
